samples.title: Fionnuala
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala (modern spellings: Fionnghuala,  Fionnuala , or  Finola; literally  meaning "white shoulder") was the daughter of Lir of the Tuatha Dé Danann. In the legend of the Children of Lir, she was changed into a swan and cursed by her stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland, with her brothers Fiachra, Conn and Aodh, for 900 years until saved by the marriage of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin, whose union broke the curse. 'The Song of Fionnuala', with lyrics by Thomas Moore speaks of her wanderings.

The name is anglicized as Fenella. The shortened version Nuala is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland.

People

 Fionnuala Boyd

Finola O'Farrell

easy_general.text:
In Irish mythology, there's a story about a girl named Finnguala. Her full name can also be spelled as Fionnghuala, Fionnuala, or Finola. This name means "white shoulder." Finnguala was the daughter of Lir, who was part of a group called the Tuatha Dé Danann.

In the story, Finnguala and her three brothers were turned into swans by their stepmother, Aoife. She cursed them to fly over lakes and rivers in Ireland for 900 years. But eventually, they were freed when Lairgren, the son of Colman and grandson of Cobthach, married Deoch, the daughter of Finghin. Their marriage broke the curse.

There's a song called "The Song of Fionnuala" written by Thomas Moore that talks about her adventures.

Today, people sometimes use the name Fenella instead of Fionnuala. The shorter name Nuala is also popular in modern Ireland.

Here are some people who have been named Fionnuala:

- Fionnuala Boyd
- Fionnuala Carr
- Fionnuala Ellwood
- Fionnuala Kenny
- Fionnuala McCormack
- Fionnuala Ní Aoláin
- Fionnuala Ní Fhlatharta
- Fionnuala Ní Flaithbheartaigh
- Fionnuala Sherry
- Fionnuala Sweeney

And here are some people named Fionnula:

- Fionnula Flanagan

And here are some people named Finola:

- Finola Dwyer
- Finola Hughes
- Finola Moorhead
- Finola O'Donnell
- Finola O'Farrell

This story is part of Irish myths about shape-shifting, which means changing into different forms, and about legendary birds and female creatures.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Irish mythology, there's a story about a girl named Finnguala. Her full name means "white shoulder" in Irish. She was the daughter of Lir, a powerful figure from ancient Irish legends. In the tale called "The Children of Lir," Finnguala, along with her brothers Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh, was turned into swans by their stepmother, Aoife, who was jealous. They were cursed to fly over lakes and rivers in Ireland for 900 long years. But eventually, the curse was broken when Lairgren, the son of Colman and grandson of Cobthach, married Deoch, the daughter of Finghin. This happy ending freed the swans from their curse.

The name "Finnguala" has been adapted to different spellings like Fenella or Nuala. Today, Nuala is a common first name in Ireland.

Many people have chosen this name for their children. Here are a few examples:

adult_technical.text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala, alternatively spelled Fionnghuala, Fionnuala, or Finola (literally meaning "white shoulder"), is the daughter of Lir, a figure from the Tuatha Dé Danann, a mythological race in Irish folklore. In the narrative known as "The Children of Lir," Finnguala, along with her siblings Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh, is transformed into swans and cursed by their stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland for 900 years. This curse is lifted only through the union of Lairgnen, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin. The tale is referenced in "The Song of Fionnuala," with lyrics penned by Thomas Moore, which recounts her journey.

The name has been anglicized as Fenella and is commonly abbreviated as Nuala, often used as a given name in modern Ireland.

Notable individuals bearing the name include:

Fionnuala Boyd, Fionnuala Carr, Fionnuala Ellwood, Fionnuala Kenny, Fionnuala McCormack, Fionnuala Ní Aoláin, Fionnuala Ní Fhlatharta, Fionnuala Ní Flaithbheartaigh, Fionnuala Sherry, and Fionnuala Sweeney.

Other variations such as Fionnula Flanagan and Finola Dwyer, Finola Hughes, Finola Moorhead, and Finola O'Donnell, Finola O'Farrell also exist.

This entry touches upon elements of shapeshifting, legendary birds, and female mythical beings within the broader context of the Irish mythological cycle.

samples.title: Sluis-Aardenburg
samples.original_text:
Sluis-Aardenburg was a municipality in the province of Zeeland, in the south-western part of the Netherlands. It was created from a merger of Sluis and Aardenburg in 1995, and it merged with the municipality of Oostburg, on 1 January 2003, to form the new municipality of Sluis.  Sluis-Aardenburg covered an area of 83.48 km², of which 0.89 km² was water.

The municipality comprised the following towns, villages and townships:
Aardenburg
Draaiburg
Eede
Heille
Retranchement
Sint Anna ter Muiden
Sint Kruis
Sluis
Terhofstede
Zwindorp

easy_general.text:
This is a list of different kinds of dogs, both ones that still exist today and some that are gone forever.

**Dogs Still Around Today**

- A to C
- D to K
- L to R
- S to Z

**Dogs That Are Gone**

These are breeds, types, or variations of dogs that no longer exist.

**Notes**

**References**
- Books and other sources used to gather information.

For example, there are many common dog breeds like Golden Retrievers (which start with G) and Poodles (which start with P). Some breeds, like the Dodo Dog, are not around anymore because they became extinct.

adult_non_technical.text:
This article lists different types of dogs, both those that exist today and those that are no longer around. It also includes various subcategories like different breeds, types, and varieties.

Existing Dog Breeds

The first section covers all the dog breeds that are still alive today. These are organized into four groups based on their names starting with letters from A to C, D to K, L to R, and S to Z.

Extinct Dog Breeds, Varieties, and Types

The second part talks about dog breeds, types, and varieties that are no longer with us. This section provides information on why these breeds became extinct and what they were like.

Notes, References, Citations, and Bibliography

At the end of the article, there are notes, references, citations, and a bibliography. These sections help verify the information provided and give credit to the sources used.

For example, if you're looking for information on a specific breed, you can find it under the appropriate letter range. If you want to know more about breeds that are no longer around, you'll find that information in the second part of the article.

adult_technical.text:
This document provides a comprehensive list of dog breeds, encompassing both extant and extinct varieties, as well as types and sub-varieties. The classification is organized alphabetically into distinct sections for clarity.

**Extant Breeds**

The section on extant breeds is divided into four main categories: A–C, D–K, L–R, and S–Z. Each category contains detailed information on the breeds within that range, including their characteristics, origins, and current status.

**Extinct Breeds, Varieties, and Types**

A separate section documents extinct breeds, varieties, and types, offering insights into historical canine diversity that no longer exists. This part includes detailed descriptions and historical context for each entry.

**Notes**

Additional notes provide supplementary information and explanations that enhance the understanding of the listed breeds and varieties.

**References**

A comprehensive list of references is provided to support the information presented in the document. These sources include academic papers, historical records, and other authoritative materials.

**Citations**

Detailed citations are included for each reference, ensuring accuracy and traceability of the information.

**Bibliography**

The bibliography lists all the sources used in compiling this document, providing a complete record of the scholarly and historical resources consulted.

**Introduction**

The document begins with a brief introduction to the significance of dog breeds, highlighting the importance of both extant and extinct varieties in understanding canine evolution and history.

samples.title: Appendix
samples.original_text:
Appendix may refer to:

In documents
Addendum, an addition made to a document by its author after its initial printing or publication
Bibliography, a systematic list of books and other works
Index (publishing), a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document

Anatomy
Appendix (anatomy), a part of the human digestive system
Appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct of the epididymis
Appendix testis, a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct
Epiploic appendix, one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum
Appendix of the laryngeal ventricle, a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle
Mesoappendix, the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix

Arts and media
Appendix (band), a Finnish punk rock group
The Appendix, a quarterly journal of history and culture

See also
 Appendicitis

easy_general.text:
Appendix can mean different things depending on the context:

Documents:
- Addendum: This is extra information added to a document after it was first printed or published.
- Bibliography: It's a list of all the books and other sources used in a project.
- Index: In publishing, this is a list of words or phrases with pages where you can find more information about them.

Anatomy:
- Appendix: A small part of your digestive system.
- Appendix of the epididymis: A tiny tube connected to the testicles.
- Appendix testis: A small leftover piece from fetal development.
- Epiploic appendix: Small fatty pouches found along parts of your large intestine.
- Appendix of the laryngeal ventricle: A small sac near the voice box.
- Mesoappendix: The part of the tissue that connects the end of the small intestine to the appendix.

Arts and Media:
- Appendix (band): A punk rock group from Finland.
- The Appendix: A magazine that talks about history and culture.

Remember, if you have pain in your lower right belly, it could be appendicitis, which is when the appendix gets inflamed.

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "appendix" can mean different things depending on the context. Here’s what it refers to in various fields:

**Documents:**
- **Addendum:** This is like a new page or section added to a document after it was first printed or published. It's useful for adding important information that wasn't included originally.
- **Bibliography:** This is a list of all the books and other sources used in a research project or document. It helps readers find the original sources if they want more information.
- **Index (in publishing):** This is a list of key words or topics in a document, along with page numbers showing where you can find more details about each topic.

**Human Body:**
- **Appendix (anatomy):** This is a small, tube-like structure attached to the large intestine. It's part of our digestive system but isn’t essential for survival.
- **Appendix of the Epididymis:** This is a tiny tube that carries sperm from the testicles.
- **Appendix Testis:** This is a small leftover piece of tissue from when we were developing in the womb.
- **Epiploic Appendix:** These are little fatty pouches found on the lining of the large intestine and rectum. They help protect the intestines.
- **Appendix of the Laryngeal Ventricle:** This is a small sac that extends from a part of the throat.
- **Mesoappendix:** This is the part of the tissue that holds the appendix in place.

**Arts and Media:**
- **Appendix (band):** This is a Finnish punk rock group known for their energetic music.
- **The Appendix:** This is a quarterly magazine that explores history and culture.

For more information, you might want to look up **Appendicitis**, which is a condition where the appendix becomes inflamed and can cause serious health issues.

adult_technical.text:
Appendix:

In Documentation:
- Addendum: An additional section appended to a document subsequent to its initial publication or printing.
- Bibliography: A comprehensive list of sources cited or referenced in a document.
- Index (publishing): A structured list of terms or topics with corresponding page references for locating specific content within a document.

Anatomical Structures:
- Appendix (anatomy): A diverticulum of the cecum, forming part of the large intestine and considered a vestigial organ in humans.
- Appendix of the Epididymis: A detached efferent ductlet of the epididymis, typically a vestigial structure.
- Appendix Testis: A remnant of the Müllerian duct, often present as a small, fibrous cord near the testis.
- Epiploic Appendix: One of several small, fatty outpouchings of the peritoneum along the colon and rectum.
- Appendix of the Laryngeal Ventricles: A small sac extending from the laryngeal ventricle, which is a part of the upper respiratory tract.
- Mesoappendix: The portion of the mesentery that attaches the ileum to the vermiform appendix, providing vascular supply and mobility.

Cultural References:
- Appendix (band): A Finnish punk rock group.
- The Appendix: A quarterly academic journal focusing on history and cultural studies.

Related Concepts:
- Appendicitis: Inflammation of the appendix, a common medical condition requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

samples.title: Hreiðmarr
samples.original_text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr (Old Norse: ; anglicized as Hreidmar) is a sorcerer. He is featured in the Völsunga saga and in Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr was the father of Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr and Lofnheiðr. He owned a house of glittering gold and flashing gems built by Regin and guarded by Fafnir. After Otr was accidentally killed by Loki, the Æsir repaid Hreiðmarr with Andvari's gold and the ring Andvaranaut, a magical ring that could create gold. However, Andvari had cursed the ring to bring misfortune and destruction to whoever else possessed it. Hreiðmarr ignored Loki's warnings about the curse and kept the ring, only to have Fafnir and Regin later kill him for it. Fafnir decided he wanted Andvaranaut for himself, so he turned into a dragon and drove Regin away. Fafnir guarded the treasure until Sigurd, on Regin's instigation, arrived and delivered a fatal blow to the dragon. Regin was then also killed by Sigurd while attempting to murder him for the ring, thus leaving all of Hreiðmarr's family dead.

See also
Völsung Cycle

References

Other sources
Byock, Jesse L. (1990) Saga of the Volsungs: The Norse Epic of Sigurd the Dragon Slayer (University of California Press) 
Orchard, Andy (1997)  Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend  (Cassell & Co)

External links
The Saga of the Volsungs, a summary in English



Völsung cycle
Norse dwarves
Nibelung tradition

easy_general.text:
In Norse mythology, there's a character named Hreiðmarr. He was a powerful wizard who lived a long time ago. Hreiðmarr had five children: Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. He lived in a beautiful house made of gold and shiny stones, which his son Regin helped build. Fafnir, another son, protected their home.

One day, Loki, a trickster god, accidentally killed Ótr. To make up for this, the Æsir (a group of gods) gave Hreiðmarr a pile of gold and a magical ring called Andvaranaut. But Andvaranaut was cursed. It would bring bad luck and trouble to anyone who owned it. Despite this warning from Loki, Hreiðmarr took the gold and the ring.

Later, Fafnir and Regin killed Hreiðmarr because they wanted the Andvaranaut ring. Fafnir turned into a big, fierce dragon and kept the treasure for himself. Regin was forced to leave. Eventually, a brave warrior named Sigurd came along and killed Fafnir. Regin was also killed by Sigurd, trying to take the ring from him.

This story is part of a larger set of tales called the Völsung Cycle. It includes many other stories about Norse gods and heroes.

For more information, you can read books like "Saga of the Volsungs" by Jesse L. Byock or "Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend" by Andy Orchard. There's also a summary of the Völsung saga available online.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Norse mythology, there’s a character named Hreiðmarr, who was like a wizard or sorcerer. He appears in old stories called the Völsunga saga and Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr had several children: Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. He lived in a fancy house made of gold and sparkling jewels, which his son Regin helped build and his other son Fafnir guarded.

One day, Loki, a trickster god, accidentally killed Ótr. To make amends, the Æsir (a group of gods) gave Hreiðmarr a pile of gold and a magical ring called Andvaranaut. But this ring had a dark curse—it brought bad luck and trouble to anyone who owned it.

Despite Loki warning him about the curse, Hreiðmarr took the ring anyway. Later, Fafnir and Regin killed their father because they wanted the ring for themselves. Fafnir then turned into a big, fierce dragon and took over the treasure. Regin was forced to leave.

Sigurd, another hero, came along at Regin’s suggestion and killed Fafnir. But when Sigurd tried to take the ring, Regin tried to kill him. In the end, both Sigurd and Regin were killed, and Hreiðmarr’s whole family was gone.

This story is part of a larger set of tales known as the Völsung Cycle. If you want to learn more, you can read books like "Saga of the Volsungs" by Jesse L. Byock or "Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend" by Andy Orchard. There are also summaries available online if you’re interested.

adult_technical.text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr, a sorcerer, is a prominent figure in the Völsunga saga and Snorri Sturluson’s Prose Edda. He is the progenitor of Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. Hreiðmarr resided in a house of gleaming gold and shimmering gemstones, which were constructed by his son Regin and guarded by Fafnir. Following the accidental death of Ótr at the hands of Loki, the Æsir compensated Hreiðmarr with Andvari’s gold and the ring Andvaranaut, a magical artifact capable of generating gold. However, Andvari had placed a curse upon the ring, predicting misfortune and destruction for any who possessed it.

Despite Loki’s warnings, Hreiðmarr disregarded the curse and retained the ring. This decision led to his demise when both Fafnir and Regin later murdered him for the ring. Fafnir coveted the Andvaranaut and transformed into a dragon, expelling Regin from his home. Fafnir then took up residence in the treasure hoard, where he remained until Sigurd, acting on Regin’s instructions, arrived and slew him. Regin, in a final act of treachery, attempted to assassinate Sigurd for the ring, resulting in his own death. Consequently, all members of Hreiðmarr’s family perished.

For further reading, see the Völsung Cycle, which encompasses the broader narrative context. Additional references include Jesse L. Byock’s translation of the Völsunga saga (1990) and Andy Orchard’s Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend (1997).

External resources for more detailed information include summaries and translations of the Völsunga saga.

This account is part of the Völsung cycle, which also includes narratives involving Norse dwarves and the Nibelung tradition.

samples.title: Turpin Hills, Ohio
samples.original_text:
Turpin Hills is a census-designated place (CDP) outside of  Anderson Township, Hamilton County, Ohio, United States. The population was 5,099 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Turpin Hills is located at  (39.103620, -84.375073).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
At the 2000 census there were 4,960 people, 1,741 households, and 1,448 families living in the CDP. The population density was 1,668.5 people per square mile (644.8/km). There were 1,810 housing units at an average density of 608.9/sq mi (235.3/km).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 96.63% White, 0.62% African American, 0.34% Native American, 1.63% Asian, 0.30% from other races, and 0.46% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.07%.

Of the 1,741 households 42.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.0% were married couples living together, 6.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 16.8% were non-families. 13.6% of households were one person and 4.0% were one person aged 65 or older. The average household size was 2.85 and the average family size was 3.16.

The age distribution was 30.6% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 26.0% from 25 to 44, 29.2% from 45 to 64, and 9.0% 65 or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 96.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.1 males.

The median household income was $84,354 and the median family income  was $93,471. Males had a median income of $63,077 versus $36,795 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $39,094. About 0.4% of families and 1.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 0.5% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Hamilton County, Ohio
Census-designated places in Ohio

samples.title: Lyfing
samples.original_text:
Lyfing (from leof, meaning "darling") is an Anglo-Saxon given name. Notable people bearing this name include:

 Lyfing, Archbishop of Canterbury (died 1020), advisor to King Ethelred the Unready
 Lyfing of Winchester (died 1047), advisor to King Canute the Dane

easy_general.text:
The name "Lyfing" comes from the Old English word "leof," which means "darling." This was a common name used by people in Anglo-Saxon times. Here are two famous people who had this name:

2. Lyfing also served as an advisor to King Canute the Dane. Canute ruled England from 1016 to 1035. He died in 1047.

adult_non_technical.text:

adult_technical.text:

1. Lyfing, who served as the Archbishop of Canterbury from 995 to 1020, during the reign of King Ethelred the Unready (r. 978–1016, 1017–1018, 1018–1019, 1019–1023). Lyfing was a significant advisor to King Ethelred.

samples.title: Girringun National Park
samples.original_text:
Girringun National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, approximately  southwest of Ingham,  north of Townsville and  northwest of Brisbane.  The park is one of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area series of national parks, and is a gazetted World Heritage Site.

History
The park was originally named the Lumholtz National Park, after scientist Carl Sofus Lumholtz, when it was created in 1994. The Blencoe Falls Section was gazetted as part of Lumholtz National Park in 2000. The name was subsequently changed to Girringun in 2003.  On National Parks Day 2010 (28 March) the Government of Queensland announced the addition of  to the park.

Environment

This large national park consists mainly of wet sclerophyll forests, but small pockets of rainforest also exist along the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George and Cardwell ranges dominate the landscape, which is strewn with granite debris from a volcanic eruption 100,000 years ago. Perhaps the most well known geological feature in this park is the Wallaman Falls. At  it is the largest single-drop falls in Australia.  The park forms part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, identified as such by BirdLife International because it supports populations of a range of bird species endemic to Queensland's Wet Tropics.

Access and infrastructure
Vehicle access into the forest include the Dalrymple Gap Track, or the Wallaman Falls track. However, for most of the park there is only very rudimentary or absent vehicle access. Most of the park is accessible for hikers, but due to its remoteness and rugged terrain only experienced bushwalkers should undertake extensive hikes.

See also

 Herbert River Falls
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Far North Queensland
Protected areas established in 1994
Wet Tropics of Queensland
1994 establishments in Australia
Important Bird Areas of Queensland

easy_general.text:
Girringun National Park is a big nature reserve in Queensland, Australia. It's about southwest of a town called Ingham, north of another town called Townsville, and northwest of Brisbane.

History
In 1994, the park was first called Lumholtz National Park, named after a scientist named Carl Sofus Lumholtz. In 2000, a section called Blencoe Falls was added to the park. In 2003, the park's name was changed to Girringun. On March 28, 2010, the government added more land to the park on National Parks Day.

Environment
The park has mostly wet forests, but there are also small areas of rainforest along the eastern hills. The main features of the landscape are the Seaview, George, and Cardwell ranges. These ranges were formed by a big volcanic eruption about 100,000 years ago, leaving behind lots of rocks. One of the most famous places in the park is Wallaman Falls, which is the tallest waterfall in Australia at 500 meters high. The park is also home to many birds that can only be found in this area.

Access and Infrastructure
There are two main roads into the forest: the Dalrymple Gap Track and the Wallaman Falls track. Most of the park is hard to reach by car, but it's easier to walk. Hiking is popular here, but only experienced hikers should attempt long walks because the area is remote and the terrain is rough.

Related Information
For more details, you might want to look up information about Herbert River Falls and other protected areas in Queensland.

adult_non_technical.text:
Girringun National Park is a beautiful protected area located in Queensland, Australia. It’s about southwest of Ingham, north of Townsville, and northwest of Brisbane. This park is part of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area, which means it’s recognized globally for its unique and important natural features.

### History

The park was first called Lumholtz National Park, named after the scientist Carl Sofus Lumholtz, who lived from 1851 to 1922. It was officially established in 1994. In 2000, a section called Blencoe Falls was added to the park. The name was then changed to Girringun in 2003. On National Parks Day in 2010, the Queensland government announced more land additions to the park.

### Environment

Girringun National Park is mostly covered in wet forests, where trees keep their leaves year-round. There are also small areas of rainforest along the eastern slopes and at the tops of hills. The park’s landscape is dominated by the Seaview, George, and Cardwell mountain ranges. These mountains were formed from volcanic rock that erupted around 100,000 years ago. One of the most famous features in the park is Wallaman Falls, which is the tallest single-drop waterfall in Australia, standing at over 300 meters high.

The park is also home to many birds that are found nowhere else in the world. It has been designated as an Important Bird Area by BirdLife International.

### Access and Infrastructure

Visitors can enter the park via the Dalrymple Gap Track or the Wallaman Falls track. However, much of the park is difficult to reach by car, and there’s very little road access. For those who love hiking, the park offers plenty of trails, but only experienced hikers should attempt longer treks due to the remote and rugged terrain.

### Related Information

If you’re interested in other nearby attractions, you might want to check out Herbert River Falls. For more information on protected areas in Queensland, you can look up the list of national parks in Far North Queensland or the protected areas established in 1994.

### References

- National parks of Far North Queensland

- Wet Tropics of Queensland
- 1994 establishments in Australia
- Important Bird Areas of Queensland

adult_technical.text:
Girringun National Park is situated in Queensland, Australia, approximately southwest of Ingham, north of Townsville, and northwest of Brisbane. It is part of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area series of national parks and is itself a designated World Heritage Site.

### History

Originally established in 1994, the park was named Lumholtz National Park, honoring the scientist Carl Sofus Lumholtz. In 2000, the Blencoe Falls Section was added to the park. The name was changed to Girringun in 2003. On National Parks Day in 2010 (March 28), the Queensland Government announced an expansion of the park.

### Environment

Girringun National Park encompasses a significant area dominated by wet sclerophyll forests, with smaller pockets of rainforest found along the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George, and Cardwell ranges are prominent features of the landscape, which includes granite debris resulting from a volcanic eruption about 100,000 years ago. Notably, the park is home to the Wallaman Falls, the largest single-drop waterfall in Australia at 350 meters. Additionally, the park is recognized as part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, as designated by BirdLife International, supporting populations of various endemic bird species of Queensland's Wet Tropics.

### Access and Infrastructure

Vehicle access within the park is limited, with tracks such as the Dalrymple Gap Track and the Wallaman Falls track being the primary routes. For the majority of the park, vehicle access is either rudimentary or non-existent. Hiking is feasible throughout much of the park, but given its remote location and challenging terrain, only experienced bushwalkers should undertake extensive treks.

### Related Topics

samples.title: FYI
samples.original_text:
"FYI" is a common abbreviation of "for your information".

"FYI" is commonly used in email, instant messaging and other messages to indicate an informational message, with an intent to communicate to the receiver that they may be interested in the given topic, but does not suggest any action or require a response.  It is also commonly used in informal and business spoken conversations.

The usage of "FYI" dates back at least as far as 1941.

Among Internet Standards, FYIs are a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series. The FYI series of notes is designed to provide Internet users with a central repository of information about any topics which relate to the Internet.  FYIs topics may range from historical memos on  "Why it was done that way" to answers to commonly asked operational questions.

References

Initialisms

easy_general.text:
"FYI" stands for "For Your Information."

People often use "FYI" in emails, chats, and other messages to share something that might interest the person receiving it. It doesn't mean the person has to do anything or reply. You can also hear "FYI" in casual or professional talks.

The term "FYI" has been around since at least 1941.

In internet standards, "FYI" is part of a bigger group called Request for Comments (RFC). The FYI section collects information about various topics related to the internet. This can include explanations of why things were done a certain way or answers to common questions about how the internet works.

For example, someone might send an "FYI" email about a new policy at work or share a link to an interesting article about the internet.

adult_non_technical.text:
"FYI" stands for "For Your Information," and it's a term you might see often in emails, chats, or any other kind of message. When someone sends you something marked as FYI, they're letting you know that the information might be interesting or relevant to you, but they don't expect you to do anything specific or reply. This term is used both in casual conversations and in professional settings.

The practice of using "FYI" has been around since at least 1941. In the world of internet standards, "FYI" is part of a larger group called Request for Comments (RFC). The FYI section of the RFCs is like a library where anyone can find information about various aspects of the internet. These topics can cover everything from the history behind certain decisions to how to solve common problems.

So, next time you see "FYI" in a message, remember that it’s just a friendly way of sharing information without expecting a response!

adult_technical.text:
The term "FYI," an abbreviation for "For Your Information," is widely utilized in various communication mediums, including emails, instant messaging platforms, and other forms of digital correspondence. This term serves to denote that the message is purely informational and intended to inform the recipient about a topic of potential interest without necessitating any specific action or response. Its usage extends to both informal and formal contexts, including business communications.

The origins of "FYI" can be traced back to at least 1941, indicating its long-standing presence in communication practices. In the realm of internet standards, "FYI" constitutes a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series, specifically designated as the FYI series. These notes serve as a comprehensive resource for internet users, providing a centralized repository of information on a wide array of topics relevant to the internet ecosystem. The scope of FYI documents is broad, encompassing everything from historical explanations of design decisions ("Why it was done that way") to practical answers addressing frequently encountered operational issues.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 1413, which began on a Sunday according to the Julian calendar, several significant events took place around the world.

### Major Events

- **March 21**: Henry V became the new King of England after his father, Henry IV, passed away.
- **July 5**: In a battle called Çamurlu, Mehmed I defeated his brother Musa, ending a period of uncertainty known as the Ottoman Interregnum.
- **August 28**: The University of St Andrews in Scotland received official recognition from the Pope.
- **October 2**: Poland and Lithuania united under the Union of Horodło, creating a stronger alliance between these two countries.

### Other Notable Events

- Around this time, the last pagan region in Europe, Samogitia, converted to Christianity.
- The Korean royal records, known as the Annals of the Joseon Dynasty, started being written.
- In Russia, a leader named Yishiha built a Buddhist temple and erected a stone marker detailing his journey to the lower Amur River.

### The Start of a New Era

1413 marks the beginning of what some spiritual thinkers call the Aquarius Age, part of a larger cycle that started in 747 BC. They believe this era might signify the end of our current way of life on Earth.

### People Born in 1413

- **February 24**: Louis, who later became the Duke of Savoy.
- **September 8**: Catherine of Bologna, a nun who lived a cloistered life.
- **November 19**: Frederick II, who would become the Elector of Brandenburg.
- **Unknown Date**: Joanot Martorell, a Spanish writer.

### People Who Died in 1413

- **January 25**: Maud de Ufford, the Countess of Oxford.
- **March 20**: Henry IV of England.
- **July 5**: Musa Çelebi, a prince and co-ruler of the Ottoman Empire.
- **September 26**: Stephen III, Duke of Bavaria.
- **October 6**: Dawit I of Ethiopia.
- **December 26**: Michele Steno, the Doge of Venice.

These events paint a picture of a dynamic time in history, marked by political changes, religious conversions, and cultural developments.

adult_technical.text:
The year 1413 (MCDXIII) was a common year beginning on a Sunday according to the Julian calendar. This period marks the transition between the earlier Epoch, which commenced in 747 BCE, and the subsequent Aquarius Age, which is considered to have initiated in 1413 AD.

### Significant Events

- **March 21**: Henry V ascended to the throne of England upon the death of his father, Henry IV.
- **July 5**: The Battle of Çamurlu concluded with Mehmed I's victory over his brother Musa, effectively ending the Ottoman Interregnum.
- **August 28**: The University of St Andrews in Scotland received its charter through a papal bull.
- **October 2**: The Kingdom of Poland and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania formalized their union through the Union of Horodło.

### Notable Historical Milestones

- **Unknown Date**: Samogitia became the final European region to be Christianized.
- **Korea**: The Annals of the Joseon Dynasty commenced.
- **Russia**: Yishiha constructed a Buddhist temple at Tyr and erected a stele detailing his expedition to the lower Amur.

### Epoch Transition

1413 AD is marked as the commencement of the current Epoch, known as the Aquarius Age, following the preceding Epoch that began in 747 BCE. Some spiritual scientists posit that this new Epoch signifies the terminal phase of human existence on Earth.

### Notable Births

- **February 24**: Louis, Duke of Savoy (d. 1465)
- **September 8**: Catherine of Bologna, an Italian cloistered nun (d. 1463)
- **November 19**: Frederick II, Elector of Brandenburg (d. 1471)
- **Unknown Date**: Joanot Martorell, a Spanish writer (d. 1468)

### Notable Deaths

- **January 25**: Maud de Ufford, Countess of Oxford (b. 1345)
- **March 20**: Henry IV of England (b. 1367)
- **July 5**: Musa Çelebi, an Ottoman prince and co-ruler (b. 1382)

BTR Aerospace Group was a group of four companies formed in 1985 by BTR plc after the acquisition of the Dunlop Aviation Division from Dunlop Rubber. It comprised Dunlop Aviation Division, Aero Engine Equipment, Dunlop Precision Rubber, and Standard Aero (Canada).

In 1996, Dunlop Aircraft Tyres Limited was sold by BTR plc to form an independent company. It is based at Fort Dunlop, Birmingham, England. 

In July 1998, Doughty Hanson & Co purchased BTR Aerospace Group and renamed it Dunlop Standard Aerospace Group.

samples.title: Extragalactic astronomy
samples.original_text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the branch of astronomy concerned with objects outside the Milky Way galaxy. In other words, it is the study of all astronomical objects which are not covered by galactic astronomy.

The closest objects in extragalactic astronomy include the galaxies of the Local Group, which are close enough to allow very detailed analyses of their contents (e.g. supernova remnants, stellar associations). As instrumentation has improved, distant objects can now be examined in more detail and so extragalactic astronomy includes objects at nearly the edge of the observable universe. Research into distant galaxies (outside of our local group) is valuable for studying aspects of the universe such as galaxy evolution and Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) which give insight into physical phenomena (e.g.  super massive black hole accretion and the presence of dark matter). It is through extragalactic astronomy that astronomers and physicists are able to study the effects of General Relativity such as gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, that are otherwise impossible (or nearly impossible) to study on a galactic scale.

Famous examples 

 Hubble Deep Field
 LIGO's detection of gravitational waves
 Chandra Deep Field South

Topics 
Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), Quasars
Dark Matter
Galaxy clusters, Superclusters
Intergalactic stars
Intergalactic dust
 the observable universe
Radio galaxies
Supernovae
Extragalactic planet

See also
 Andromeda–Milky Way collision
 Galaxy color–magnitude diagram
 Galaxy formation and evolution
 Observational cosmology

References

 
Astronomical sub-disciplines
Physical cosmology
Edwin Hubble

easy_general.text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the study of objects beyond our Milky Way galaxy. This field looks at galaxies and other cosmic structures far away from us.

The nearest objects studied in this field are the galaxies in the Local Group. These galaxies are close enough for scientists to study in great detail, like looking at supernova remnants or groups of stars together.

As technology has improved, we can now study galaxies much farther away. This means extragalactic astronomy covers objects near the edge of what we can see in the universe. Studying these distant galaxies helps us understand how galaxies change over time and learn about active galactic nuclei (AGN). AGN are super bright centers of galaxies that tell us about supermassive black holes and dark matter.

Extragalactic astronomy also helps us study General Relativity, a theory about gravity. Scientists can observe things like gravitational lensing (where light bends due to gravity) and gravitational waves (ripples in space-time) that are hard to see within our own galaxy.

Some famous studies in this field include:

- The Hubble Deep Field: A very deep image of space taken by the Hubble Space Telescope.
- LIGO’s detection of gravitational waves: An experiment that detected ripples in space-time.
- The Chandra Deep Field South: A detailed X-ray image of a small part of the sky.

Key topics in extragalactic astronomy include:

- Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN): Bright centers of galaxies.
- Dark Matter: A mysterious substance that makes up a large part of the universe.
- Galaxy Clusters and Superclusters: Large groups of galaxies.
- Intergalactic Stars and Dust: Stars and dust between galaxies.
- The Observable Universe: All the space we can see.
- Radio Galaxies: Galaxies that emit lots of radio waves.
- Supernovae: Explosions of stars.
- Extragalactic Planets: Planets in other galaxies.

For more information, you might want to look into:

- The Andromeda–Milky Way collision: When our galaxy will eventually collide with the Andromeda galaxy.
- Galaxy Color–Magnitude Diagram: A way to classify galaxies based on their brightness and color.
- Galaxy Formation and Evolution: How galaxies form and change over time.
- Observational Cosmology: The study of the universe using observations.

This field is closely related to physical cosmology, which is the study of the universe as a whole. One of its pioneers was Edwin Hubble, who discovered that galaxies are moving away from

adult_non_technical.text:
Extragalactic astronomy focuses on studying objects beyond our Milky Way galaxy. This field includes everything from nearby galaxies within our Local Group to those at the farthest reaches of what we can see in the universe.

The Local Group, which includes galaxies like the Andromeda galaxy, is close enough for us to study in great detail. We can observe features like exploded stars (supernovae) and groups of young stars. As our tools have gotten better, we can now examine even the most distant galaxies, almost at the edge of what we can see. Studying these distant galaxies helps us understand how galaxies change over time and learn about mysterious phenomena like supermassive black holes and dark matter.

Extragalactic astronomy also allows us to explore concepts like gravity in ways we can't do within our own galaxy. For example, we can observe how gravity bends light (gravitational lensing) and detect ripples in space-time caused by colliding black holes (gravitational waves).

Some famous studies in this field include:

- The Hubble Deep Field, which captured images of extremely distant galaxies.
- The detection of gravitational waves by LIGO, a groundbreaking achievement.
- The Chandra Deep Field South, which provided detailed X-ray images of distant galaxies.

Key topics in extragalactic astronomy include:

- Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN): These are supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies that emit intense radiation.
- Dark Matter: A mysterious substance that doesn't interact with light but affects the motion of galaxies.
- Galaxy Clusters and Superclusters: Large groups of galaxies bound together by gravity.
- Intergalactic Stars and Dust: Stars and dust found between galaxies.
- The Observable Universe: The part of the universe we can observe from Earth.
- Radio Galaxies: Galaxies that emit large amounts of radio waves.
- Supernovae: Explosions of stars that can briefly outshine entire galaxies.
- Extragalactic Planets: Planets orbiting stars in other galaxies.

This field is closely related to other areas of astronomy, such as galaxy formation and evolution, observational cosmology, and the upcoming Andromeda–Milky Way collision. Notable figures in this area include Edwin Hubble, who made significant contributions to our understanding of the universe.

adult_technical.text:
Extragalactic astronomy focuses on celestial objects beyond the Milky Way galaxy, encompassing the study of distant galaxies, galaxy clusters, and other cosmic entities that lie outside our local galactic environment. This field leverages advanced observational techniques and instrumentation to explore phenomena ranging from nearby galaxies within the Local Group to those at the farthest reaches of the observable universe.

### Scope and Objectives

Extragalactic astronomy plays a crucial role in understanding various cosmic processes, including galaxy evolution, the nature of active galactic nuclei (AGN), and the behavior of supermassive black holes. The study of AGN provides insights into accretion processes and the distribution of dark matter within and around galaxies. Additionally, this discipline enables researchers to investigate the effects of general relativity, such as gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, phenomena that are challenging to observe on a galactic scale.

### Notable Observations and Discoveries

Key observations and discoveries in extragalactic astronomy include:

- **Hubble Deep Field**: A series of images taken by the Hubble Space Telescope that revealed thousands of galaxies in a small patch of sky, providing a snapshot of the early universe.
- **LIGO’s Detection of Gravitational Waves**: The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) detected ripples in spacetime caused by the merging of black holes and neutron stars, offering direct evidence of these extreme astrophysical events.
- **Chandra Deep Field South**: High-resolution X-ray images captured by the Chandra X-ray Observatory, revealing the presence of hot gas and energetic processes in distant galaxies.

### Core Topics

The field of extragalactic astronomy encompasses several key areas of research:

- **Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN)**: Central regions of galaxies that emit intense radiation due to the accretion of matter onto supermassive black holes.
- **Dark Matter**: Non-luminous material that constitutes a significant portion of the universe's mass-energy content, inferred through its gravitational effects on visible matter.
- **Galaxy Clusters and Superclusters**: Large-scale structures composed of hundreds or thousands of galaxies bound together by gravity.
- **Intergalactic Stars and Dust**: Stellar remnants and dust particles that exist between galaxies, contributing to the intergalactic medium.
- **Observable Universe**: The region of space that can be observed from Earth given the finite speed of light and the age of the universe.
- **Radio Galaxies**: Galaxies that emit significant amounts of radio waves, often associated with powerful jets and

easy_general.text:

adult_non_technical.text:
In Hawaiian mythology, there's a god named Laʻa Maomao who rules over the winds. According to old stories, he was born during a time of great confusion, when his father, the sun god, created him. Laʻa Maomao is generally seen as a kind and forgiving figure.

- Raka Maomao, another wind god

These gods are part of the larger group known as Hawaiian gods, which includes many different spirits and deities. Among these, the wind deities are those who control the air and the breezes.

adult_technical.text:
In Hawaiian mythology, Laʻa Maomao is the deity associated with the wind. According to legend, he was born amidst cosmic disorder as the offspring of the sun god. Generally considered a beneficent figure, Laʻa Maomao is also revered as the god of forgiveness.

For further reference, see Raka Maomao and Fa'atiu.

Notes:

- **Hawaiian Gods**: This category encompasses various deities worshipped in ancient Hawaiian religion, each with specific domains and attributes.
- **Wind Deities**: Laʻa Maomao, along with other deities such as Raka Maomao and Fa'atiu, falls under this classification, reflecting their role in controlling and manifesting wind phenomena.

samples.title: Geneva Township, Freeborn County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Geneva Township is a township in Freeborn County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 439 at the 2000 census.

Geneva Township was organized in 1858.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which   is land and   (7.24%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 439 people, 156 households, and 126 families residing in the township.  The population density was 13.3 people per square mile (5.1/km2).  There were 168 housing units at an average density of 5.1/sq mi (2.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.63% White, 0.23% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.23% from other races, and 0.68% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.51% of the population.

There were 156 households, out of which 42.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 70.5% were married couples living together, 6.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 16.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.81 and the average family size was 3.12.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.9% under the age of 18, 6.8% from 18 to 24, 27.6% from 25 to 44, 25.7% from 45 to 64, and 10.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.2 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $46,563, and the median income for a family was $48,594. Males had a median income of $27,045 versus $28,438 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,674.  About 3.2% of families and 5.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 6.1% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Freeborn County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: 266 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 266 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor (or, less frequently, year 488 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 266 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 January 23 – Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrate triumphs over the Salentini.
 Calabria and Messapia are annexed by the Roman Republic.

 Asia Minor 
 Ariobarzanes becomes the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father Mithridates I Ctistes.

 India 
 The Mauryan emperor Ashoka converts to Buddhism.

Births 
 Berenice II, queen and co-regent of Egypt (or 267 BC)

Deaths 
 Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao (b. 310 BC)
 Mithridates I Ctistes, founder of the kingdom of Pontus

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 266 BC:

- This was a time before the Julian calendar was used in Rome.
- It was also called the 488th year since Rome was founded.
- People started using the year 266 BC around the Middle Ages.

Events:

- In Rome, two leaders named Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo had big celebrations because they won battles against a group called the Salentini.
- The areas of Calabria and Messapia were added to the Roman Republic.

- In Asia Minor (a region near Turkey), a man named Ariobarzanes became the second king of Pontus after his father, Mithridates I Ctistes, passed away.

- In India, the ruler Ashoka changed his beliefs to Buddhism.

People Born:

- A woman named Berenice II was born in Egypt. She later became queen and shared power with another person (or she could have been born in 267 BC).

People Who Died:

- A Chinese king named Huiwen of Zhao died at the age of about 50.
- Mithridates I Ctistes, who started the kingdom of Pontus, also died.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 266 BC, which was before the Julian calendar was introduced, Rome was ruled by two leaders called consuls named Pera and Pictor. This year is also known as the 488th year since the founding of Rome. People have been using the year 266 BC to mark events ever since the Middle Ages, when a new way of dating years based on the birth of Christ became popular in Europe.

### Events

#### In Rome
- **January 23**: Two Roman generals, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo, held big victory parades after defeating a group called the Salentini.
- **Calabria and Messapia**: These areas were added to the territory controlled by the Roman Republic.

#### In Asia Minor
- **Ariobarzanes**: He became the second king of a region called Pontus, following in the footsteps of his father, Mithridates I Ctistes.

#### In India
- **Ashoka**: The ruler of the Mauryan Empire converted to Buddhism.

### Births
- **Berenice II**: She was born around this time and later became the queen and shared rule with her husband in Egypt (or possibly in 267 BC).

### Deaths
- **Huiwen of Zhao**: He was a king of China who lived until 266 BC.
- **Mithridates I Ctistes**: He was the founder of the kingdom of Pontus and passed away in 266 BC.

These events show how different parts of the world were changing during this period, with new rulers emerging and empires expanding.

adult_technical.text:
In the year 266 BC, which corresponds to the 488th year from the founding of Rome according to the Ab urbe condita chronology, significant events transpired across various regions. This date is commonly denoted as 266 BC in historical records, reflecting the adoption of the Anno Domini system during the early medieval period.

### Events

#### Roman Republic
On January 23, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrated triumphs over the Salentini, marking a military victory. Subsequently, the territories of Calabria and Messapia were annexed by the Roman Republic, expanding its control in southern Italy.

#### Asia Minor
Ariobarzanes succeeded his father Mithridates I Ctistes as the second king of Pontus, establishing himself as a prominent ruler in the region.

#### India
The Mauryan emperor Ashoka converted to Buddhism, a pivotal moment in the spread of this religion.

### Births
Berenice II, who would later become the queen and co-regent of Egypt, was born around 266 BC (or possibly in 267 BC).

### Deaths
Huiwen of Zhao, the Chinese king of Zhao, passed away in 266 BC, having ruled from 310 BC. Additionally, Mithridates I Ctistes, the founder of the kingdom of Pontus, also died in this year.

These events highlight the political and religious dynamics of the late 3rd century BC, including military expansions, dynastic changes, and religious transformations.

samples.title: Kilo Ali
samples.original_text:
Andrell D. Rogers (born May 1, 1973), better known as Kilo Ali, formerly Kilo, is an American rapper from Atlanta, Georgia. Kilo Ali recorded mainly bass music (described more closely to Miami bass style music), but also hip-hop tracks with a less distinctive Southern flavor. His most well known singles include "Show Me Love", "Baby Baby", and "Love In Ya Mouth".

As Kilo Ali, he released Organized Bass in 1997 on Interscope, with featured artists including George Clinton, Cee-Lo of Goodie Mob, Big Boi of OutKast, and JT Money. In 2011, Ali was released from prison after serving six years of a 15-year sentence for arson. In June 2021, Ali sued rapper NLE Choppa for copyright infringement for unauthorized use of his 1997 song, "Love In Ya Mouth".

 1993: Bluntly Speaking

 1994: The Best And the Bass
 1995: Get This Party Started (No. 57 U.S. Rap)
as Kilo Ali
 1997: Organized Bass (No. 173 U.S., No. 44 U.S. Rap)
 2010: Sa-La-Meen
 2011: Hieroglyphics

Singles

adult_technical.text:
Andrell D. Rogers, known professionally as Kilo Ali and previously as Kilo, is an American rapper hailing from Atlanta, Georgia. His musical output primarily encompasses bass music, with notable influences from the Miami bass genre, though he has also ventured into hip-hop with a less pronounced Southern accent. Among his most recognized singles are "Show Me Love," "Baby Baby," and "Love In Ya Mouth."

Kilo Ali's discography includes several releases under various monikers. His debut album, "America Has a Problem," was released in 1991, followed by "A-Town Rush" in 1992, which peaked at number 67 on the U.S. Rap chart. Other notable works include "Bluntly Speaking" (1993), "Git Wit Da Program" (1993), "The Best And the Bass" (1994), "Get This Party Started" (1995), and "Organized Bass" (1997) under the Kilo Ali moniker. This latter release, produced by Interscope Records, featured collaborations with prominent artists such as George Clinton, Cee-Lo Green (formerly of Goodie Mob), Big Boi (of OutKast), and JT Money. In 2010, he released "Sa-La-Meen," and in 2011, "Hieroglyphics."

In 2011, Kilo Ali was released from a 15-year prison sentence, having served six years for arson. He subsequently filed a lawsuit against rapper NLE Choppa in June 2021, alleging copyright infringement for the unauthorized use of his 1997 hit "Love In Ya Mouth."

Kilo Ali's professional affiliations include Ichiban Records, and he is recognized as a living individual, a 21st-century American rapper, and a 21st-century African-American musician. His career spans both the late 20th and early 21st centuries, with significant contributions to the bass and hip-hop genres.

samples.title: Slow fire
samples.original_text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe paper embrittlement resulting from acid decay. The term is taken from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record.

Solutions to this problem include the use of acid-free paper stocks, reformatting brittle books by microfilming, photocopying or digitization, and a variety of deacidification techniques.

See also
Acid-free paper
Double Fold
Wood-pulp paper
Preservation: Library and Archival Science

External links
 International Journal of Library Science 
Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts
 Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record
 Slow fires at IMDB

Preservation (library and archival science)

easy_general.text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe how paper can become weak and brittle over time due to acid decay. This term comes from a 1987 film called "Slow Fires" about preserving important records.

To fix this problem, libraries and archives can use special paper that doesn't contain acids. They can also make copies of old, fragile books using microfilm, photocopies, or digital scans. Another method is to treat the paper with chemicals to remove the acids.

Some key terms to know:
- Acid-free paper: Paper made without harmful acids that can damage documents over time.
- Double Fold: A controversial method of preserving old newspapers by scanning them and creating new copies.
- Wood-pulp paper: Regular paper made from wood, which can deteriorate quickly.

For more information, you can read articles in the International Journal of Library Science or watch the film "Slow Fires." There are also external resources like "Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts" and "Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record."

Preservation is an important part of library and archival science, focusing on protecting and maintaining historical documents and materials.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the world of libraries and information management, "slow fire" is a term used to describe how paper can become brittle and weak over time due to acid decay. This concept comes from a 1987 film titled "Slow Fires," which focuses on preserving important records for future generations.

To combat this issue, several methods can be employed:

1. **Using Acid-Free Paper**: This means using paper that doesn't contain acids, which can cause the paper to weaken and break down over time.
2. **Reformatting Books**: This involves creating new copies of old, fragile books. One way to do this is through microfilming, where the book is photographed onto a thin film. Another method is digitization, which scans the pages into digital files.
3. **Deacidification Techniques**: These are processes designed to remove or neutralize the acids in paper, helping to preserve its integrity.

Some key terms you might come across include:

- **Acid-free Paper**: Paper that has been treated to prevent it from becoming acidic and breaking down.
- **Double Fold**: A method of scanning documents that involves taking two photographs of each page from slightly different angles to ensure no part of the document is missed.
- **Wood-pulp Paper**: Regular paper made from wood fibers, which can be prone to acid decay.

For more detailed information, you can explore resources like the International Journal of Library Science, which discusses various preservation strategies. There are also films and articles available, such as "Extinguishing Slow Fires: Cooperative Preservation Efforts" and "Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record," which delve deeper into these topics.

Understanding these concepts is crucial for anyone involved in managing and preserving historical documents and books.

adult_technical.text:
In the field of library and information science, the term "slow fire" is employed to denote the progressive degradation of paper due to acid hydrolysis, a process that leads to embrittlement and eventual deterioration of the material. This nomenclature is derived from Terry Sanders' 1987 documentary, "Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record."

Addressing this issue involves several strategies. Acid-free paper stocks can be utilized to mitigate the onset of acid decay. For already deteriorated materials, alternative formats such as microfilming, photocopying, or digitization can preserve the content while rendering the original paper obsolete. Additionally, various deacidification techniques are available to neutralize existing acids within the paper, thereby slowing down the degradation process.

Related concepts include acid-free paper, which is designed to resist acid hydrolysis, and wood-pulp paper, which is more susceptible to acid decay. The broader context of preservation in library and archival science encompasses these specific issues and employs a range of methodologies to ensure the longevity of historical records and documents.

For further reading and resources, consider consulting the International Journal of Library Science, which publishes research on preservation techniques. Specific works include "Extinguishing Slow Fires: Cooperative Preservation Efforts," which discusses collaborative approaches to document preservation, and Terry Sanders' documentary, "Slow Fires: On the Preservation of the Human Record." Additional information can be found on the Internet Movie Database (IMDb) entry for the film.

The overarching discipline of preservation in library and archival science focuses on safeguarding cultural heritage through the application of scientific and technical knowledge.

4. It's the name of a college in India called Rajdhani College.
5. In Burkina Faso, there's a village named Raka.
6. In Tibet, there's another village with this name.
7. In a small town in Slovenia called Krško, there's a village named Raka.
8. In Estonia, there are two villages named Raka—one in Järva County and another in Rapla County.

3. There's a place in Tibet called Raka Maomao.
4. In some countries, there are places named Raka. For example, there's a village in a place called Krško in Slovenia, another in Estonia near a town called Ambla, and yet another in Rapla in Estonia.

6. In 2019, two music groups from Australia released a collection of songs called "Raka."

If you come across "Raka" and aren't sure what it means, you might want to check a list of similar names to find out which one it is. There's also a special award called the RAKA Award given to someone named Kate Challis.

The term "Raka" is multifaceted and can refer to various entities across different contexts:

samples.title: Francis Hyacinth, Duke of Savoy
samples.original_text:
Francis Hyacinth (; 14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638) was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638 under regency of his mother  Christine Marie.

Biography

Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin he was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy and his wife Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who had died in 1628 prior to the birth of Francis Hyacinth.

At his father's death in October 1637, he succeeded and his mother took power having been claimed regent. While Duke of Savoy he also held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, count of Aosta, Moriana and Nice, and claimant King of Jerusalem. The infant was nicknamed the Flower of Paradise (French: Fleur de Paradis). Having succeeded his father at such a young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto being only 5 years old. Having caught a fever, he died at the Castle of Valentino, and was succeeded by his brother Charles Emmanuel II. The infant was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Ancestry

Biography

As the next in line to be the Duke, he was called the Prince of Piedmont. His father had another son who passed away before Francis Hyacinth was born.

When Francis Hyacinth's father died in October 1637, Francis Hyacinth became the Duke. His mother, Christine Marie, took charge as the regent, which means she made decisions for him since he was too young to rule himself. During his brief time as Duke, he held several other titles like Marquess of Saluzzo and Count of Aosta. People also called him the "Flower of Paradise."

Because he was just five years old, Francis Hyacinth didn't actually rule. He got sick with a fever and died at the Castle of Valentino. His younger brother, Charles Emmanuel II, became the new Duke after him. Francis Hyacinth was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Ancestry

Francis Hyacinth was born in 1632 and died in 1638. He was part of the 17th-century Dukes of Savoy and the nobility from Turin. He was also known as the Prince of Piedmont and a claimant to the title of King of Jerusalem. Sadly, he was one of many rulers who died while still a child.

Francis Hyacinth (14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638) served as the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638 under the regency of his mother, Christine Marie of France.

Biography

Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin, Francis Hyacinth was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy, and Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had previously lost a younger son in 1628 before the birth of Francis Hyacinth.

Upon his father’s death in October 1637, Francis Hyacinth ascended to the throne at the tender age of five. His mother, Christine Marie, assumed the role of regent. During his brief tenure as Duke of Savoy, he held several subsidiary titles, including Marquess of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Moriana, and Nice, and was a claimant to the title of King of Jerusalem. He was affectionately known as the "Flower of Paradise" (Fleur de Paradis) in French circles. Due to his young age, Francis Hyacinth did not exercise de facto rule. He succumbed to a fever at the Castle of Valentino and was succeeded by his brother, Charles Emmanuel II. The young duke was interred at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

Abel-mizraim (, ’Āḇêl-Mitsrayim,; the "meadow of Egypt", or "mourning of Egypt") is a place "beyond," or east, of the Jordan river, at the "threshing-floor of Atad." Here Joseph and his 11 brothers (representing the future 12 tribes of Israel) and the Egyptians mourned seven days for Jacob (Genesis ). Its exact site is unknown.

The name Abel-mizraim is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.
