samples.title: Sour mix
samples.original_text:
Sour mix (also known as sweet and sour mix) is a mixer that is yellow-green in color and is used in many cocktails. It is made from approximately equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup and shaken vigorously with ice. This produces a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavor.

Optionally, egg whites may be added to make the liquid slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor(s) to make a sour drink; most common are vodka sour (vodka) and whiskey sour (whiskey).

Pre-mixed versions are available, and are in use in many bars.  These typically consist of a powder which must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.

See also
List of cocktails

Drink mixers

easy_general.text:
Sour mix, also called sweet and sour mix, is a yellow-green drink mix used in cocktails. It's made by mixing lemon or lime juice with simple syrup (a sweetener made from sugar and water) in equal parts. When shaken with ice, it becomes a white, flavorful liquid.

Sometimes, egg whites are added to make the drink a bit foamy.

You can mix sour mix with different types of alcohol to create sour drinks. The most common ones are a vodka sour (using vodka) and a whiskey sour (using whiskey).

Some places sell pre-made sour mix in powder form. Before using it, you need to add water to rehydrate it.

For more information on drinks, check out lists of cocktails and drink mixers.

adult_non_technical.text:
Sour mix, sometimes called sweet and sour mix, is a popular ingredient in cocktails. It's a bright green-yellow color and is made by mixing lemon or lime juice with sugar syrup (simple syrup). When you shake this mixture with ice, it creates a creamy white liquid with a tangy taste.

Sometimes, people add egg whites to make the drink a bit frothy.

To make a sour drink, you mix sour mix with different types of alcohol. The most common ones are a vodka sour (using vodka) and a whiskey sour (using whiskey).

In bars, you can find pre-made sour mix in powder form. To use it, you need to mix the powder with water before adding it to your drink.

If you're interested in learning more about drinks, you might want to check out lists of different cocktails and their mixers.

adult_technical.text:
Sour mix, also referred to as sweet and sour mix, is a versatile cocktail mixer characterized by its distinctive yellow-green hue. Its primary components are lemon and/or lime juice combined with simple syrup, typically in equal proportions. When vigorously shaken with ice, this mixture yields a pearly-white liquid with a robust tart-sweet flavor profile.

An optional addition of egg whites can enhance the texture, creating a slightly foamy consistency.

Sour mix is commonly used to create classic cocktails such as the vodka sour and the whiskey sour. Pre-mixed versions, often available in powdered form, require hydration with water before use and are widely employed in bar settings.

For further reading on related topics, see "List of Cocktails" and "Drink Mixers."

samples.title: Lucerne Mines, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Lucernemines, usually written as Lucerne Mines, is a census-designated place (CDP) in Indiana County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 937 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Lucerne Mines is located at  (40.554447, -79.155584).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 951 people, 407 households, and 293 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,105.8 people per square mile (427.0/km2). There were 427 housing units at an average density of 496.5/sq mi (191.7/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.63% White, 1.05% African American, 0.11% Asian, and 0.21% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.84% of the population.

There were 407 households, out of which 23.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.2% were married couples living together, 10.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 27.8% were non-families. 25.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 15.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. samples.title: Worth Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Worth Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States.  The population was 899 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 25.0 square miles (64.8 km2), of which, 24.8 square miles (64.2 km2) of it is land and 0.2 square miles (0.6 km2) of it (0.96%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 830 people, 319 households, and 238 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.5 people per square mile (12.9/km2).  There were 329 housing units at an average density of 13.3/sq mi (5.1/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.28% White, 0.12% Asian, 0.24% Pacific Islander, and 0.36% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.24% of the population.

There were 319 households, out of which 34.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.5% were married couples living together, 5.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 25.1% were non-families. 20.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.04.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 29.2% from 25 to 44, 24.1% from 45 to 64, and 15.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 100.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 106.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $41,328, and the median income for a family was $46,719. Males had a median income of $30,573 versus $21,818 for females. The per capita income for the township was $18,434.  About 5.3% of families and 8.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.6% of those under age 18 and 4.2% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Kiho
samples.original_text:
Kiho may refer to:

 Kiho-tumu, the supreme god in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago
 Kihō, Mie, a town in Japan
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions, but generate spell effects.  Kiho nearly always require a shugenja or monk (sometimes specifically one or the other) to bow as part of the cost of playing the card
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja that have some extraordinary or supernatural effect

People with the given name
, Japanese women's basketball player

Japanese feminine given names

easy_general.text:
"Kiho can mean different things:

1. **Kiho-tumu**: This is the main god in the stories of the Tuamotu islands.
2. **Kihō, Mie**: This is a town in Japan.
3. **In the Legend of the Five Rings Card Game**: Kiho are special cards that players use like actions. To play them, they usually need to bow first, either as a shugenja (a kind of wise person who uses magic) or a monk.
4. **In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game**: Kiho are advanced fighting moves that monks and sometimes shugenjas learn. These moves can do amazing or magical things.

There is also a person named Kiho, who is a basketball player from Japan. Additionally, Kiho is a common name for girls in Japan."

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "kiho" can mean different things depending on the context:

1. **In Tuamotu Mythology**: Kiho-tumu is the highest god in the beliefs of people who live in the Tuamotu islands. This god is considered the most powerful and important deity in their religious stories.

2. **In Japan**: Kihō is a town located in the Mie prefecture of Japan. It’s just a place name and doesn’t have any special meaning beyond being a location.

3. **In the Legend of the Five Rings Card Game**: Kiho refers to special action cards. When you play these cards, they create magical effects similar to spells. To use these cards, you usually need to have a character called a shugenja or a monk, and they must perform a bow as part of the process.

4. **In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game**: Kiho are advanced fighting techniques used by monks and sometimes shugenjas (who are like wise and powerful magic users). These techniques can do amazing or supernatural things.

5. **A Person Named Kiho**: There’s also a person named Kiho, who is a professional basketball player in Japan. She plays for women’s teams and competes at high levels of the sport.

6. **Japanese Names**: Finally, "kiho" is a common Japanese girl’s name, often given to girls born in Japan.

So, "kiho" can be a god, a place, a card game move, a fighting technique, a person’s name, or simply a name for baby girls in Japan.

adult_technical.text:
The term "kiho" can denote several distinct concepts across different contexts:

1. **Kiho-tumu**: This refers to the supreme deity in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago, a group of islands in the South Pacific.

2. **Kihō, Mie**: This is a specific town located in Mie Prefecture, Japan.

3. **Legend of the Five Rings (L5R) Collectible Card Game**: In this game, "kiho" cards function as action cards that produce spell effects when played. Typically, their activation requires a shugenja or monk (or sometimes specifically one of these roles) to perform a bowing gesture as part of the play cost.

4. **Legend of the Five Rings (L5R) Role-Playing Game**: Here, "kiho" represents advanced martial arts techniques mastered by monks and occasionally shugenja. These techniques often possess extraordinary or supernatural properties.

Additionally, "kiho" is also used as a given name, particularly for Japanese women, and as a general term for female names in Japanese culture.

samples.title: SS7
samples.original_text:
SS7 or SS-7 may refer to:

 Signalling System No. 7, a set of telephone signaling protocols
 SS-7 Saddler, the NATO reporting name of R-16 missile
 China Railways SS7, an electric locomotive model in China
 Super Socket 7, a chip socket introduced by AMD

easy_general.text:
SS7 can mean different things:

1. **Signalling System No. 7**: This is a set of rules used by phone companies to make sure calls work properly. It's like a special language that helps phones talk to each other.

2. **SS-7 Saddler**: This is another name for the R-16 missile, which was used by NATO countries. NATO gives special names to weapons for identification purposes.

3. **China Railways SS7**: This is a type of train engine used in China. It's an electric train that helps move people and goods around.

4. **Super Socket 7**: This is a kind of socket used for computer chips made by AMD. A socket is where you put the chip into the computer to make it work.

adult_non_technical.text:
SS7, which can sometimes be written as SS-7, refers to different things depending on the context:

1. **Signalling System No. 7 (SS7)**: This is a set of rules that help phones communicate with each other. Imagine it like a traffic system for phone calls and texts, making sure they get where they need to go smoothly.

2. **SS-7 Saddler**: This is actually a nickname given by NATO (a group of countries working together) to a type of missile called R-16. It's not related to phone communication at all.

3. **China Railways SS7**: In China, this term describes a specific type of electric train used to pull passenger cars. Think of it as a special kind of locomotive designed for moving people around efficiently.

4. **Super Socket 7 (SS7)**: This is a type of connector used in computer chips made by AMD. It's like a plug that fits into a specific slot to connect different parts of a computer.

Each of these uses of "SS7" has a completely different meaning, but they all share the same basic number, 7, in their names.

adult_technical.text:
The term "SS7" or "SS-7" can have multiple meanings depending on the context:

1. **Signalling System No. 7 (SS7)**: This refers to a comprehensive suite of telecommunication protocols that facilitate the operation of public switched telephone networks (PSTNs) and mobile networks. SS7 enables various services such as call routing, short message service (SMS), and supplementary services like call waiting and three-way calling.

2. **SS-7 Saddler**: In military and intelligence contexts, SS-7 Saddler is the NATO reporting name for the R-16 ballistic missile, developed by the Soviet Union. This designation is used in classified documents and reports for consistent reference.

3. **China Railways SS7**: This denotes a specific model of electric locomotive used by China's railway system. The SS7 series is part of China's advanced fleet of modern electric locomotives designed for high-speed rail operations.

4. **Super Socket 7 (Socket 7)**: This is a type of socket for CPU sockets, particularly associated with AMD processors. Introduced in the late 1990s, Socket 7 was widely used for Pentium II and early Celeron processors, facilitating the installation and upgrading of CPUs in personal computers.

samples.title: Muslim brotherhoods of Senegal
samples.original_text:
This is a list of Sufi orders (Tariqas) in Senegal (and also the Gambia).  They are active Muslim organizations that can also be found in many other parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Their members are mainly Wolofs, Fulas and Tocouleurs.

List
The four largest Muslim brotherhoods in Senegal are:

 The Xaadir (Qādiriyya), the oldest, founded in Baghdad by the Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century, now pan-Islamic, spread to Senegal in the 18th Century.
 The Tijaniyyah, the largest in membership, founded in Fez, Morocco by the Algerian born Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
 The Mourides, the richest and most active, founded by the Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850–1927) of French West Africa, now Senegal. The order is centered in the city of Touba.
 The Layene are a smaller Sufi order, centered at Yoff north of Dakar.

External links
 Review of Sufism and Religious Brotherhoods in Senegal
 BBC:Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

Senegal
Islam in Senegal
Lists of Muslims
Sufi orders

easy_general.text:
In Senegal and the Gambia, there are special Muslim groups called Sufi orders. These groups are part of larger Muslim organizations found across Africa and the Islamic world. Most members of these groups are Wolofs, Fulas, and Tocouleurs.

Here are the four biggest Sufi groups in Senegal:

1. **Xaadir (Qādiriyya)**: This is the oldest group, started by a man named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in Baghdad in the 12th century. It spread to Senegal in the 18th century.

2. **Tijaniyyah**: This is the biggest group in terms of members. It was started by a man named Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī in Fez, Morocco. The main center of this group is in a town called Tivaouane.

3. **Mourides**: This group is very rich and active. It was started by a religious leader named Cheikh Amadou Bamba in French West Africa, which is now Senegal. The main center is in a city called Touba.

4. **Layene**: This is a smaller group, with its main center in a place called Yoff, just north of Dakar.

For more information, you can read about Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal or learn about Senegal's Mourides, who are known as mystical entrepreneurs.

To find out more about Senegal and its Muslims, check out these resources:

- A review of Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal
- BBC article on Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

If you want to know more about Muslims in Senegal, look at lists of Muslims and Sufi orders.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Senegal and its neighboring country, the Gambia, there are several Sufi orders, which are like big groups of Muslims who follow similar spiritual practices. These groups are part of a larger tradition found across much of Africa and the Islamic world. Most of their members come from three main ethnic groups: Wolofs, Fulas, and Tocouleurs.

Here are the four biggest Sufi orders in Senegal:

1. **Xaadir (Qādiriyya)**: This is the oldest group, started by a man named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in Baghdad around the year 1100. It’s now a worldwide organization and came to Senegal in the 1700s.

2. **Tijaniyyah**: This is the largest group in terms of members. It was founded by a man named Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī in Fez, Morocco. The group has its headquarters in the city of Tivaouane.

3. **Mourides**: This is the wealthiest and most active group. It was started by a religious leader named Cheikh Amadou Bamba in what was then French West Africa, now Senegal. The group’s main center is in the city of Touba.

4. **Layene**: This is a smaller group, centered in a place called Yoff, which is near the capital city of Dakar.

These groups play a significant role in the lives of many people in Senegal, offering spiritual guidance and community support.

For more information, you can read about Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal or learn about Senegal's Mourides, a group known for its unique blend of spirituality and business success.

If you want to know more about Islam in Senegal or other lists of Muslims, these resources might help.

adult_technical.text:
This document outlines the prominent Sufi orders (tariqas) operating in Senegal and the Gambia, which are also widespread throughout much of Africa and the broader Islamic world. The members of these orders are predominantly from ethnic groups such as the Wolof, Fulani, and Toucouleur.

### List of Major Sufi Orders in Senegal

1. **Qādiriyya (Xaadir)**: This is the oldest tariqa among those listed, founded in the 12th century by the Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in Baghdad. It has since become pan-Islamic and was introduced to Senegal in the 18th century. The Qādiriyya order is centered in various regions across Senegal, but notable centers include Tivaouane.

2. **Tijaniyyah**: This is the largest in terms of membership, established in Fez, Morocco, by the Algerian-born Sheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The Tijaniyyah order is particularly prominent in the city of Tivaouane, where its headquarters are located.

3. **Mourides**: This is the wealthiest and most active tariqa, founded by the Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850–1927) during the colonial period in French West Africa, now Senegal. The Mouride movement is centered in the city of Touba, which has become a significant pilgrimage site.

4. **Layene**: This is a smaller Sufi order, centered in Yoff, a suburb north of Dakar. While less prominent than the others, it still plays a role in the local religious landscape.

### External Resources

For further reading, consider reviewing scholarly works on Sufism and religious brotherhoods in Senegal, as well as articles on the Mourides, who are known for their entrepreneurial activities within the Islamic community.

### Contextual Information

- **Islam in Senegal**: A comprehensive overview of Islam's presence and influence in Senegal.
- **Lists of Muslims**: Additional resources providing information on various Muslim communities and organizations.
- **Sufi Orders**: General information on Sufi orders and their significance in Islamic tradition.

This structured approach provides a clear and detailed account of the major Sufi orders in Senegal, supported by relevant external references for deeper exploration.

adult_non_technical.text:
ICMP can mean different things depending on the context:

In Science and Technology:
- International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants (ICMP) is a place in New Zealand where they keep and study plant-based microorganisms.
- Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is a tool used in computer networks to send error messages and other important information between devices.

adult_technical.text:
ICMP can denote several distinct entities across various fields:

In Science and Technology:
- International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants (ICMP), a culture collection based in New Zealand.
- Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP), a protocol utilized in computer networking for transmitting error messages and other operational information between network nodes.

In Medicine:
- Ischemic cardiomyopathy, a form of heart disease characterized by reduced blood flow to the myocardium.

In Organizations:
- Institute of Contemporary Music Performance (ICMP) in London, UK.
- International Commission on Missing Persons (ICMP), an intergovernmental organization focused on identifying missing persons through DNA analysis and other forensic methods.

samples.title: Stormarn (district)
samples.original_text:
Stormarn () is a district in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is bounded by (from the north and clockwise) the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein, the city of Lübeck, the district of Lauenburg, and the city-state of Hamburg.

History

In medieval times the name Stormarn was applied to a larger area, of which the present-day district is only the eastern half. It was the home of the Saxon tribe the Sturmarii.

Stormarn became a part of Holstein in the 12th century.  When Schleswig-Holstein became a province of Prussia in 1867, the Prussian administration established the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its capital. In 1937 the southwestern part of the district was incorporated into Hamburg, and the district lost half of its population. Since Wandsbek was now a borough of Hamburg, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe after the war. In 1970 Stormarn again lost a substantial portion of its territory, when the city of Norderstedt was founded in order to become a part of the Segeberg district.

Geography

The river Trave runs through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. In the southernmost portion of Stormarn there are the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

Coat of arms
The coat of arms displays a white swan, with a crown around its neck, on red ground. The swan has been the heraldic animal of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Towns and municipalities

References

External links
Official website (German)

Districts of Schleswig-Holstein
Regions of Schleswig-Holstein

easy_general.text:
Stormarn is a district in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It borders four other areas: Segeberg and Ostholstein to the north, the city of Lübeck, and the district of Lauenburg. To the east lies the city-state of Hamburg.

History

A long time ago, the area known as Stormarn was much bigger than it is today. The present district is just the eastern part. This land was once home to a group called the Sturmarii, who were part of the Saxons.

In the 12th century, Stormarn became part of a region called Holstein. When Schleswig-Holstein joined Prussia in 1867, the Prussian government made Stormarn a district with Wandsbek as its main town.

In 1937, a part of Stormarn was added to Hamburg, making Stormarn smaller. After World War II, the capital moved to Bad Oldesloe because Wandsbek became part of Hamburg. In 1970, another piece of Stormarn became the new city of Norderstedt, which joined the Segeberg district.

Geography

The river Trave flows through Stormarn before reaching Lübeck. In the southern part of Stormarn, you can find some of the suburbs of Hamburg.

Coat of Arms

The symbol of Stormarn features a crowned white swan on a red background. This swan has been used as a symbol for Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Cities and Towns

References

For more information, visit the official website of Stormarn (in German).

Other Districts in Schleswig-Holstein
There are other districts in Schleswig-Holstein, including Segeberg and Ostholstein.

adult_non_technical.text:
Stormarn is a region in the state of Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It borders four other regions: Segeberg and Ostholstein to the north and east, the city of Lübeck to the south, and the city-state of Hamburg to the west.

### History

In the Middle Ages, the name Stormarn referred to a much larger area than today's district. This area was home to a group called the Sturmarii, who were part of the Saxon tribe. By the 12th century, Stormarn had become part of Holstein. When Schleswig-Holstein joined Prussia in 1867, the Prussian government set up the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its main town. In 1937, a part of Stormarn was added to Hamburg, reducing its size and population by half. After World War II, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe because Wandsbek had become part of Hamburg. In 1970, another piece of Stormarn territory was taken over by the newly formed city of Norderstedt, which then joined the Segeberg district.

### Geography

The district includes parts of the Trave River, which flows into the city of Lübeck. The southern part of Stormarn is part of the greater Hamburg area.

### Symbolism

The official symbol of Stormarn features a crowned white swan on a red background. This swan has been the symbol of the region since the Middle Ages.

### Current Towns and Cities

Stormarn includes several towns and cities, each with its own unique history and character.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Stormarn, which is available in German.

### Related Information

If you want to learn more about the other regions in Schleswig-Holstein, you can explore the list of districts and regions in the state.

adult_technical.text:
**Stormarn District**

**Administrative Context**
Stormarn is a district located in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is bordered by the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein, the city of Lübeck, the district of Lauenburg, and the city-state of Hamburg. Its current boundaries encompass only the eastern half of the historical region known as Stormarn, which extended further north in medieval times.

**Historical Overview**
In the medieval period, the term "Stormarn" denoted a much larger territory than the present district. This region was historically inhabited by the Saxon tribe, the Sturmarii. By the 12th century, Stormarn had become part of the Duchy of Holstein. Following the unification of Schleswig-Holstein under Prussian rule in 1867, the Prussian administration delineated the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek designated as its capital. In 1937, the southwestern portion of the district was annexed by Hamburg, resulting in a significant reduction in population. Post-World War II, Wandsbek became a borough of Hamburg, prompting the relocation of the district's administrative center to Bad Oldesloe. Further territorial adjustments occurred in 1970, when the city of Norderstedt was established and incorporated into the Segeberg district, leading to another substantial loss of territory for Stormarn.

**Geography**
The district is traversed by the River Trave, which flows into the city of Lübeck. The southernmost part of Stormarn includes the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

**Coat of Arms**
The official coat of arms features a crowned white swan on a red background. This emblem has been associated with Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

**Towns and Municipalities**
The district encompasses several towns and municipalities, though specific names are not provided in the original text.

**References**
For additional information, refer to the official website of Stormarn (in German).

**Further Reading**
For a comprehensive overview of the districts and regions of Schleswig-Holstein, consult relevant geographical and historical resources.

samples.title: Europe of Democracies and Diversities
samples.original_text:
Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a Eurosceptic political group with seats in the European Parliament between 1999 and 2004. Following the 2004 European elections, the group reformed as Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

Members
June Movement (Denmark), 3 seats
People's Movement against the EU (Denmark), 1 seat
Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition (France), 6 seats
ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party (Netherlands), 3 seats
UK Independence Party (United Kingdom), 3 seats
Combats Souverainistes (France), 1 MEP defected from Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001
League of Polish Families (Poland), after Poland joined the EU in May 2004

References

External links
European Parliament Annual Accounts of Political Groups
Europe Politique
European Parliament profile of Jens-Peter Bonde
Entry on Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung

Former European Parliament party groups
Euroscepticism

sv:Demokratiernas och mångfaldens Europa

easy_general.text:
The Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a group in the European Parliament from 1999 to 2004. This group didn't like the idea of a strong European Union and wanted more power for individual countries.

Here are some details about the group:

- In Denmark, there were two main parties: the June Movement (3 seats) and the People's Movement against the EU (1 seat).
- In France, Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition had 6 seats.
- In the Netherlands, ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party had 3 seats.
- The UK Independence Party had 3 seats from the United Kingdom.
- A party called Combats Souverainistes in France changed to Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM) in 2001.
- The League of Polish Families joined in 2004 after Poland became part of the EU.

After 2004, the group changed its name to Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

adult_non_technical.text:
Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a group of politicians who were skeptical about the European Union. This group had members in the European Parliament from 1999 to 2004. After the 2004 elections, they changed their name to Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

Here’s who made up this group:

- **June Movement** from Denmark: They had 3 seats.
- **People's Movement against the EU** from Denmark: They had 1 seat.
- **Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition** from France: They had 6 seats.
- **ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party** from the Netherlands: They had 3 seats.
- **UK Independence Party** from the United Kingdom: They also had 3 seats.
- **Combats Souverainistes** from France: One member left another group called Rally for France/UEN in March 2001.
- **League of Polish Families** from Poland: They joined after Poland became part of the EU in May 2004.

These groups were all part of a larger movement that didn’t fully support the European Union. They believed in more independence for their countries within the EU.

For more information, you can look at the European Parliament’s financial reports, websites like Europe Politique, or profiles of one of their key figures, Jens-Peter Bonde. There are also articles about other similar groups and the concept of Euroscepticism.

adult_technical.text:
The Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a Eurosceptic political group that held seats in the European Parliament from 1999 to 2004. After the 2004 European elections, the group reorganized into Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

**Members:**
- **June Movement (Denmark)**: Represented by 3 Members of the European Parliament (MEPs).
- **People's Movement against the EU (Denmark)**: Represented by 1 MEP.
- **Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition (France)**: Represented by 6 MEPs.
- **ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party (Netherlands)**: Represented by 3 MEPs.
- **UK Independence Party (United Kingdom)**: Represented by 3 MEPs.
- **Combats Souverainistes (France)**: One MEP defected from the Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001.
- **League of Polish Families (Poland)**: Joined the EDD following Poland’s accession to the EU in May 2004.

**References:**

- Europe Politique
- European Parliament profile of Jens-Peter Bonde
- Entry on Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung

**Related Topics:**

**Note:** The term "MEP" refers to Members of the European Parliament.

samples.title: Punt
samples.original_text:
Punt or punting may refer to:

Boats
Punt (boat), a flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow developed on the River Thames
Falmouth Quay Punt, a small sailing vessel hired by ships anchored in Falmouth harbour
Norfolk Punt, a type of racing dinghy developed in Norfolk
Cable ferry, known as a punt in Australian English

Places
 Land of Punt, a trading partner of Ancient Egypt possibly based in the Horn of Africa region
 Puntland, a region in north-eastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province

Sports and recreation
 Punt (gridiron football), a way of kicking a ball in the American or Canadian varieties of football
 Punt (Australian football), a way of kicking a ball in the Australian variety of football
 A type of goal kick in association football

Other uses
 Punt (surname), a surname
 The Punt or Punt Éireannach, also known as the Irish pound, which was the currency of Ireland prior to its changeover to the Euro
 El Punt, a Catalan newspaper
 Punt gun, a type of extremely large shotgun, mounted directly on punt boats
 A punt or punty, a tool used in glassblowing
 A punt mark or pontil mark, left by the glassblowing tool
 Punt (wine bottle), the indented bottom of a wine bottle
 Punt, a colloquial term in British English for bet or wager in gambling
 PUNT, the Spanish acronym of the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea

See also
 Punter (disambiguation)
 Pundt

easy_general.text:
"Punt can mean different things:

Boats:
- Punt (boat): A flat-bottomed boat shaped like a square at the front, often found on the River Thames.
- Falmouth Quay Punt: A small sailing boat that ships in Falmouth harbor can hire.
- Norfolk Punt: A racing boat designed in Norfolk.
- Cable ferry: A boat used to transport vehicles across rivers, sometimes called a punt in Australia.

Places:
- Land of Punt: An ancient trading partner of Egypt, possibly located in East Africa.
- Puntland: A region in northeastern Somalia, with its capital in Garowe.

Sports and games:
- Punt (gridiron football): Kicking the ball in American or Canadian football.
- Punt (Australian football): Kicking the ball in Australian rules football.
- Punt (association football): A type of goal kick in soccer.

Other meanings:
- Punt (last name): A family name.
- Punt (currency): The old money used in Ireland before the Euro.
- Punt (newspaper): A Catalan newspaper.
- Punt gun: A very big shotgun used on boats.
- Punt (glassmaking): A tool used in making glass.
- Punt mark: A mark left by the glassmaking tool.
- Punt (wine bottle): The indented bottom of a wine bottle.
- Punt (bet): A term for a bet or wager in gambling.
- PUNT: Short for the United National Workers' Party in Equatorial Guinea.

For more information, see "Punter (disambiguation)" and "Pundt."

adult_non_technical.text:
Punt or punting can mean different things depending on the context. Here’s a simple breakdown:

**Boats**
- **Punt (boat)**: Think of a flat-bottomed boat with a squared-off front, often seen on the River Thames.
- **Falmouth Quay Punt**: A small sailing boat that ships in Falmouth harbor can hire when they're anchored.
- **Norfolk Punt**: A racing boat designed for speed, originally from Norfolk.
- **Cable Ferry**: In Australia, this is called a punt. It's a boat used to transport vehicles across rivers using cables.

**Places**
- **Land of Punt**: An ancient trading partner of Egypt, likely located in the Horn of Africa.
- **Puntland**: A region in northeastern Somalia, with its capital in Garowe.

**Sports and Recreation**
- **Punt (gridiron football)**: In American and Canadian football, it’s a method of kicking the ball.
- **Punt (Australian football)**: In Australian rules football, it’s another way to kick the ball.
- **Punt (association football)**: In soccer, it refers to a specific kind of goal kick.

**Other Uses**
- **Punt (surname)**: A last name.
- **The Punt (Irish pound)**: The old currency of Ireland before it switched to the Euro.
- **El Punt**: A Catalan newspaper.
- **Punt Gun**: A very large shotgun used on boats.
- **Punt (glassblowing)**: A tool used in making glass.
- **Punt Mark (or Pontil Mark)**: The mark left on glass by the tool used in shaping it.
- **Punt (wine bottle)**: The indentation at the bottom of a wine bottle.
- **Punt (bet)**: A casual term for a bet or wager in gambling.
- **PUNT**: The Spanish acronym for the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

For more details, you might want to check out the "Punter" disambiguation page.

adult_technical.text:
The term "punt" or "punting" encompasses a diverse array of applications across various fields, each with distinct technical definitions and uses:

1. **Vessels**:
   - **Punt (boat)**: A flat-bottomed, square-cut bow boat traditionally associated with the River Thames.
   - **Falmouth Quay Punt**: A small sailing vessel utilized by ships anchored in Falmouth harbor for transportation purposes.
   - **Norfolk Punt**: A specialized racing dinghy developed in Norfolk, England.
   - **Cable Ferry**: Known as a punt in Australian English, this is a ferry that operates by being towed across a body of water by cables.

2. **Geographical Locations**:
   - **Land of Punt**: A historical trading partner of ancient Egypt, potentially located in the Horn of Africa.
   - **Puntland**: A region in northeastern Somalia, centered around the city of Garowe in the Nugaal province.

3. **Sports and Recreation**:
   - **Punt (gridiron football)**: A method of kicking the ball in American and Canadian football.
   - **Punt (Australian football)**: A technique for kicking the ball in Australian rules football.
   - **Goal Kick in Association Football**: A specific type of kick used to restart play after a goal has been scored.

4. **Miscellaneous Uses**:
   - **Punt (surname)**: A family name.
   - **Punt (currency)**: Refers to the Irish pound, the national currency of Ireland before the adoption of the Euro.
   - **El Punt**: A Catalan newspaper.
   - **Punt Gun**: An extremely large shotgun mounted directly on a punt boat, used for hunting waterfowl.
   - **Punt (glassblowing)**: A tool used in glassblowing, often referred to as a punty.
   - **Punt Mark or Pontil Mark**: The mark left on a glass object by the punty during the manufacturing process.
   - **Punt (wine bottle)**: The indented base of a wine bottle designed to provide stability.
   - **Punt (gambling)**: A colloquial term in British English for a bet or wager.
   - **PUNT**: The Spanish acronym for the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

For further clarification, see the disambiguation page for "punter."

samples.title: Start signal
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is a signal that prepares a device to receive data or to perform a function. 

In asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a character that prepares the receiving device for the reception of the code elements. 

A start signal is limited to one signal element usually having the duration of a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
In telecommunications, a start signal is a special kind of signal that tells a device it's ready to receive information or do something.

In a type of communication called asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of each letter or symbol. They help the device that's listening know it should get ready to receive the next piece of information.

A start signal is very short and lasts only as long as one part of the basic time unit used in the system.

For example, imagine you're playing a game where you send messages using lights. Each message starts with a special light pattern that tells everyone to pay attention and get ready to read the rest of the message.

This helps make sure the message is received correctly without any mistakes.

adult_non_technical.text:
In simple terms, a start signal is like a special cue that tells a device it's time to pay attention and get ready to receive information or do something specific.

In a type of communication called asynchronous serial communication, start signals are particularly important. They mark the beginning of each piece of information (which we call a character) and let the receiving device know it should be prepared to listen for the next set of instructions or data.

Think of a start signal as a brief moment—usually just one small part of the overall signal—that lasts about as long as a single beat in a rhythm. This short signal is what tells the device to wake up and start paying attention.

This concept is key in telecommunications engineering, which is all about how we send and receive information over distances using technology.

adult_technical.text:
In telecommunications, a start signal is a pulse or condition that initiates the reception of data or triggers a specific function within a device. In the context of asynchronous serial communication, a start signal marks the beginning of a character, signaling the receiving device to prepare for the subsequent code elements. This start signal is typically a single bit with a duration equivalent to one unit interval.

For further reading, see Telecommunications engineering.

samples.title: Sibley Township, Sibley County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Sibley Township is a township in Sibley County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 353 at the 2000 census.

Sibley Township was organized in 1864.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.7 square miles (92.3 km), of which 35.6 square miles (92.2 km)  is land and 0.1 square mile (0.1 km)  (0.14%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 353 people, 115 households, and 90 families residing in the township.  The population density was 9.9 people per square mile (3.8/km).  There were 127 housing units at an average density of 3.6/sq mi (1.4/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.43% White, 0.28% African American and 0.28% Asian.

There were 115 households, out of which 43.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.8% were married couples living together, 1.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 18.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 3.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.07 and the average family size was 3.52.

In the township the population was spread out, with 30.9% under the age of 18, 10.5% from 18 to 24, 28.9% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64, and 8.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 122.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,125, and the median income for a family was $40,000. Males had a median income of $27,750 versus $20,833 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,814.  About 8.3% of families and 11.1% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 10.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Sibley County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

Sibley Township is a place in Sibley County, Minnesota, USA. In 2000, it had about 353 people living there.

Sibley Township was set up in 1864.

**Geography**
Sibley Township covers an area of about 35.7 square miles (which is like 92 football fields put together). Most of this area is land, with just a tiny bit being water—about 0.1 square mile (like a small lake).

**People**
In 2000, there were 353 people living in Sibley Township. On average, there were about 10 people per square mile. There were 115 homes, and most of these were family homes.

- **Racial Makeup:** Almost everyone was white. A very small number were African American or Asian.
- **Households:** About 43.5% of homes had kids under 18. Most homes were married couples. Some homes didn't have a husband, and some were just one person living alone.
- **Age Groups:** Young people made up about 31% of the population. People between 25 and 44 were the largest group. Fewer people were 65 or older.
- **Income:** The average money earned by a family was about $40,000. Men usually earned more than women. About 11.1% of people didn't have enough money to live comfortably.

These details give us a picture of what life was like for the people living in Sibley Township back then.

Most people in Sibley Township were white. A very small number were African American or Asian.

The average income for a household was around $39,125, and for a family, it was around $40,000. Men earned more on average than women. The money each person earned on average (per capita income) was $14,814.

samples.original_text:
Carlsbad may refer to:

Carlsbad, California, United States

easy_general.text:
Carlsbad can mean different places:

1. Carlsbad, California - a city in the United States.
2. Carlsbad, New Mexico - another city in the United States.
3. Carlsbad, Texas - a city in the United States.
4. Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic - a town in the Czech Republic, sometimes called Carlsbad.

Some other things related to Carlsbad include:

- Carlsbad Caverns National Park: a park with big caves in New Mexico.
- Carlsbad Decrees: rules made in 1849 in Prussia.
- Carlsbad Springs, Ontario: a place with natural springs in Canada.
- Carlsbad State Beach: a beach in California.
- HC Energie Karlovy Vary: a sports club in Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic.
- West Baden Springs Hotel: an old hotel in Indiana, USA.
- Karlsbad (disambiguation): helps explain when people talk about different places or things named Carlsbad.

adult_non_technical.text:
Carlsbad is a name used in several places around the world. Here’s where you can find it:

1. **Carlsbad, California**: This is a city in the United States, located in San Diego County.
2. **Carlsbad, New Mexico**: Another city in the United States, found in the state of New Mexico.
3. **Carlsbad, Texas**: A city in the United States, situated in the eastern part of the state.
4. **Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic**: Also known as Carlsbad, this is a spa town in the Czech Republic, famous for its mineral springs.

These places have something in common—they all share the name "Carlsbad," which means "bad” or “spring” in German. The name often refers to areas with natural springs or spas.

In addition to these locations, there are other things named Carlsbad:

- **Carlsbad Caverns National Park**: A park in New Mexico known for its beautiful underground caves.
- **Carlsbad Decrees**: These were a set of laws passed in 1849 in the Kingdom of Saxony, Germany, aimed at suppressing liberal movements.
- **Carlsbad Springs, Ontario**: A place in Canada known for its natural springs.
- **Carlsbad State Beach**: A beach in California.
- **HC Energie Karlovy Vary**: A spa and wellness center in Karlovy Vary, Czech Republic.
- **West Baden Springs Hotel**: A historic hotel in Indiana, USA, known for its mineral springs.

So, whenever you hear about Carlsbad, remember it could be referring to any of these places or concepts!

samples.title: Huerfano, New Mexico
samples.original_text:
Huerfano () is a census-designated place (CDP) in San Juan County, New Mexico, United States. The population was 104 at the 2000 census. It is part of the Farmington Metropolitan Statistical Area. Huerfano is named after El Huerfano Mountain, located a mile to the northeast.

Geography
Huerfano is located at  (36.526359, -108.031135).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 104 people, 28 households, and 22 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 3.9 people per square mile (1.5/km2). There were 36 housing units at an average density of 1.3 per square mile (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 99.04% Native American and 0.96% White.

There were 28 households, out of which 39.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.1% were married couples living together, 17.9% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.4% were non-families. 14.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.71 and the average family size was 4.32.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 38.5% under the age of 18, 7.7% from 18 to 24, 25.0% from 25 to 44, 20.2% from 45 to 64, and 8.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30 years. For every 100 females, there were 85.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 82.9 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $24,583, and the median income for a family was $24,583. Males had a median income of $18,750 versus $13,750 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $7,333. None of the population is below the poverty line.

Education
The community of Huerfano is part of the Bloomfield School District.

References

Census-designated places in San Juan County, New Mexico
Census-designated places in New Mexico

samples.title: FTS2000
samples.original_text:
Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a long distance telecommunications service for the United States federal government, including services such as switched voice service for voice or data up to 4.8 kbit/s, switched data at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, switched digital integrated service for voice, data, image, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s, packet switched service for data in packet form, video transmission for both compressed and wideband video, and dedicated point-to-point private line for voice and data. 

Note 1:  Use of FTS2000 contract services is mandatory for use by U.S. Government agencies for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. 

Note 2:  No U.S. Government information processing equipment or customer premises equipment other than that which are required to provide an FTS2000 service are furnished. 

Note 3:  The FTS2000 contractors will be required to provide service directly to an agency's terminal equipment interface. For example, the FTS2000 contractor might provide a terminal adapter to an agency location in order to connect FTS2000 ISDN services to the agency's terminal equipment. 

Note 4:  GSA awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts covering FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988. 

Note 5:  The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in instances related to maximum security.
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, then replaced by FTS2001, and thereafter, in 2008, by Networx.

References
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, and was replaced by FTS2001.

Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

easy_general.text:
FTS2000 is a special phone and internet service used by the U.S. government. It offers different types of communication:

- Voice calls and data up to 4.8 kilobits per second (kbit/s)
- Data transfer at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s
- Digital services for voice, data, images, and videos up to 1.544 megabits per second (Mbit/s)
- Packet-switched data
- Video transmission for both compressed and wide-band video
- Direct lines for voice and data

Here’s what you need to know about FTS2000:

1. **Mandatory Use**: All U.S. government agencies must use FTS2000 for their communications needs, unless they have special permission.

2. **No Extra Equipment**: Agencies can’t get extra equipment unless it’s needed for FTS2000 services.

3. **Direct Connection**: FTS2000 providers will connect directly to the agency’s equipment. They might use a special adapter to make the connection work.

4. **Contract Details**: In 1988, the government signed two big contracts with companies to provide these services for 10 years.

5. **Security Exceptions**: Some very secure situations don’t have to use FTS2000.

FTS2000 ended in 2000 and was replaced by FTS2001. In 2008, it was further replaced by Networx.

This service helps the government communicate better and more efficiently.

adult_non_technical.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) was a special phone and internet system designed just for the U.S. government. It offered various services like:

- Voice calls and data transfers up to 4.8 kilobits per second (kbit/s)
- Data transfers at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s
- Digital services for voice, data, images, and videos up to 1.544 megabits per second (Mbit/s)
- Packet-switched data, where information is broken into small packets for faster transfer
- Video transmission for both regular and high-quality video
- Direct lines for voice and data between specific points

Here’s what you need to know about using FTS2000:

1. **Mandatory Use**: All U.S. government agencies must use FTS2000 for their communications needs unless they fall under certain security restrictions.

2. **No Extra Equipment**: The government can’t get any extra equipment except what’s needed to use FTS2000.

3. **Connecting Services**: FTS2000 providers have to make sure their services can connect directly to the government’s equipment. They might provide special adapters to help with this connection.

4. **Contract Details**: In 1988, the government signed two big contracts with companies to provide these services for 10 years.

5. **Security Exceptions**: There are some cases where the government doesn’t have to use FTS2000 if it involves very sensitive information.

FTS2000 was finished in 2000 and was later replaced by FTS2001 in 2008, which itself was eventually replaced by a new system called Networx.

This system was part of the broader world of telecommunication services in the U.S., which includes all the ways we send and receive information over distances using phones, internet, and other technologies.

adult_technical.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a comprehensive long-distance telecommunications service tailored for U.S. federal government agencies. It encompasses a range of services, including switched voice and data services up to 4.8 kbit/s, switched data at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, switched digital integrated services for voice, data, images, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s, packet-switched data services, video transmission for both compressed and wideband formats, and dedicated point-to-point private lines for voice and data communications.

**Note 1:** The use of FTS2000 contract services is mandatory for all U.S. Government agencies under acquisitions governed by 40 U.S.C. 759.

**Note 2:** No additional U.S. Government information processing or customer premises equipment, beyond what is necessary to provide FTS2000 services, is supplied.

**Note 3:** FTS2000 contractors are obligated to deliver services directly to the agency’s terminal equipment interface. This may involve providing terminal adapters to facilitate connections between FTS2000 Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) services and the agency’s terminal equipment.

**Note 4:** The General Services Administration (GSA) awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts for FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988.

**Note 5:** The Warner Amendment exempts the mandatory use of FTS2000 in scenarios involving maximum security requirements.

FTS2000 was operational until its replacement by FTS2001 in 2000, which itself was succeeded by Networx in 2008.

**References:**
- FTS2000 was operational until 2000, when it was replaced by FTS2001.
- Telecommunication services provided by FTS2000 included switched voice and data, switched data, switched digital integrated services, packet-switched data, video transmission, and dedicated private lines.
- FTS2000 was part of the broader context of telecommunication services in the United States.

samples.title: Battle of Grotniki
samples.original_text:
The Battle of Grotniki took place on 4 May 1439 in the vicinity of Grotniki Duże, a village near Nowy Korczyn, currently in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. 

The battle was fought between the Hussite confederates under Spytko III of Melsztyn against the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland under Hińcza of Rogów and  de facto regent bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The defeat of the non-Catholic forces marked the end of militant Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom, led by bishop Zbigniew.

Bibliography
Jan Długosz, Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae, opera venerabili domini Ioanni Dlugossi, liber XI i XII, Warsaw 2001, page 202 - 206.
Secondary sources
Anna Sochacka "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny? "  Rocznik Lubelski, vol XVI, Lublin 1973.

1439 in Europe
Grotniki 1439
Grotniki 1439
Grotniki
15th century in Poland

easy_general.text:
The Battle of Grotniki happened on May 4, 1439, near a village called Grotniki Duże, which is close to Nowy Korczyn. Today, this area is part of Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship in Poland.

This battle was between two groups. One group was led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, who supported the Hussites, a group that didn't follow Catholic beliefs. The other group was led by King Władysław III of Poland and his advisors, including Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki.

The Hussites lost this battle. This defeat ended their military activities in Poland and helped King Władysław gain more control over the country. After this, Bishop Zbigniew became a very powerful leader in Poland.

For more information, you can read Jan Długosz's book "Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae," specifically pages 202 to 206. Another source is Anna Sochacka's article "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny?" published in the 1973 volume of the "Rocznik Lubelski."

This battle was part of events happening in Europe in 1439. It also marks an important moment in the history of Poland during the 15th century.

adult_non_technical.text:
In 1439, a significant battle took place near a village called Grotniki Duże, which is close to Nowy Korczyn. Today, this area is part of Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship in Poland.

This battle was a clash between two sides: the Hussite confederates, led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, and the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland. These royal forces were commanded by Hińcza of Rogów and the de facto regent, Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The Hussites were a group who didn't follow traditional Catholic practices, while the royal forces were loyal to the king and the church.

The Hussites lost this battle, which ended their militant phase in Poland. After this, the Polish Kingdom became more unified under the leadership of Bishop Zbigniew.

For more details, you can refer to historical records like Jan Długosz's "Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae," specifically pages 202-206. Another source is Anna Sochacka's article "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny?" published in the Rocznik Lubelski, volume XVI.

This battle was part of the events happening in Europe in 1439, particularly in Poland during the 15th century.

adult_technical.text:
The Battle of Grotniki occurred on May 4, 1439, near Grotniki Duże, a village located close to Nowy Korczyn, within the current boundaries of Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. This engagement pitted the Hussite confederates, led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, against the royal forces commanded by Hińcza of Rogów and the de facto regent, Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki, representing King Władysław III of Poland.

This conflict signified the culmination of the militant Hussite movement in Poland and heralded the consolidation of power within the Polish Kingdom under the leadership of Bishop Zbigniew. The defeat of the non-Catholic forces underscored the shift in political dynamics and religious influence in the region.

For detailed historical context, refer to Jan Długosz's "Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae," specifically volumes XI and XII, published in Warsaw in 2001, pages 202-206. Additional insights can be found in Anna Sochacka's article "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny?" published in the XVI volume of the "Rocznik Lubelski" in 1973.

Further reading on the broader European context of 1439 includes studies on the events at Grotniki, as well as general accounts of the 15th century in Poland.

samples.title: Dea Tacita
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita ("the silent goddess") was a goddess of the dead. Ovid's Fasti includes a passage describing a rite propitiating Dea Tacita in order to "seal up hostile mouths / and unfriendly tongue" at Feralia on 21 February. In later times, she was equated with the naiad Larunda.  In this guise, Dea Tacita was worshipped at a festival called Larentalia on 23 December. Goddesses Mutae Tacitae were invoked to destroy a hated person: in an inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia, someone asks "ut mutus sit Quartus" and "erret fugiens ut mus". These silent goddesses are the personification of terror of obscurity. Plutarch, who describes Tacita as a Muse, states that Numa Pompilius credited Tacita for his oracular insight and taught the Romans to worship her.

References

Roman goddesses
Death goddesses

easy_general.text:
In Roman mythology, there was a goddess named Dea Tacita, which means "the silent goddess." She was a goddess of the dead. According to a story by Ovid, people would perform a special ceremony on February 21 to make sure the dead stayed quiet. This ceremony was part of a day called Feralia.

Later, Dea Tacita was thought to be the same as another goddess named Larunda. People also started to honor her during a festival called Larentalia on December 23.

There were other goddesses called Mutae Tacitae, who could make someone disappear or go away. An old writing from a place called Cambodunum in Raetia mentions asking these goddesses to make a person named Quartus silent and run away like a mouse.

These silent goddesses represented fear of being forgotten or unknown. The philosopher Plutarch said that Dea Tacita was actually a Muse, a goddess of music and poetry. He believed that Numa Pompilius, an important Roman leader, learned about prophecy from Dea Tacita and taught the Romans to worship her.

This information is about Roman goddesses who were connected to death and silence.

adult_non_technical.text:
In ancient Roman mythology, there was a goddess named Dea Tacita, often referred to as "the silent goddess." She was associated with the dead and had a special role during a ceremony held on February 21st. This ceremony was meant to calm the spirits of the dead and prevent them from speaking out against the living. Later, Dea Tacita was linked to another water spirit called Larunda.

In December, on December 23rd, people celebrated a festival known as Larentalia, where they honored Dea Tacita again. Interestingly, these silent goddesses were also thought to bring about silence in a more personal way. An inscription found in Cambodunum, a town in what is now Switzerland, shows that people would pray to these goddesses to make someone else silent—specifically, they wished for a person named Quartus to be silenced and run away like a mouse.

The idea behind these silent goddesses was to represent the fear of being unknown or unheard. The philosopher Plutarch even mentioned that Dea Tacita was one of the Muses, and according to legend, King Numa Pompilius believed that Dea Tacita gave him special wisdom. He taught the Romans how to honor her, adding to her importance in their culture.

This story highlights how ancient cultures used myths and rituals to cope with the unknown and the fear of death.

adult_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita, often translated as "the silent goddess," was a deity associated with the dead. According to Ovid's *Fasti*, a ritual was performed on February 21 to appease Dea Tacita, specifically to "seal up hostile mouths and unfriendly tongues" during the festival of Feralia. Later, Dea Tacita was equated with the naiad Larunda, and in this form, she was worshipped during the Larentalia festival on December 23.

The concept of the Mutae Tacitae, or silent goddesses, is linked to the idea of eradicating a hated individual. An inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia reads, "that Quartus be mute and wander like a mouse," illustrating the invocation of these deities for malevolent purposes. The Mutae Tacitae can be seen as personifications of the fear of obscurity and silence.

Plutarch, in his writings, refers to Tacita as a Muse and attributes her influence to Numa Pompilius, the legendary second king of Rome. Numa is said to have credited Tacita with his oracular insights and taught the Romans to honor her. This association with oracular wisdom contrasts with the more malevolent aspects of the goddesses invoked for silencing enemies.

For further reading on Roman goddesses and death deities, see the references provided.

samples.title: IBM 3720
samples.original_text:
The IBM 3720 was a communications controller (front-end processor) made by IBM, suitable for use with IBM System/390. The 3720, introduced in 1986, was capable of supporting up to 60 communications lines, and was a smaller version of the 3725.  Official service support was withdrawn in 1999 in favour of the IBM 3745.

The IBM 3720 is unrelated to the similarly-numbered IBM 3270 display terminal system.

References

External links
IBM 3720 Communication Controller Service Guide (PDF)

3720

easy_general.text:
The IBM 3720 was a special computer made by IBM. It was used to connect different parts of a big mainframe computer called the IBM System/390. This computer could handle up to 60 communication lines, which means it could connect to 60 different devices at once. It was like a smaller version of another similar IBM computer called the 3725.

The IBM 3720 first came out in 1986. People stopped getting help with it in 1999 because they started using a newer model called the 3745 instead.

The IBM 3720 is not the same as another computer with a similar number, the IBM 3270 display terminal system. That one was used for displaying information on screens, while the 3720 was more about connecting different parts of a computer system.

For more details, you can look at the IBM 3720 Communication Controller Service Guide (PDF).

adult_non_technical.text:
The IBM 3720 was a special computer made by IBM that helped connect other computers together. It was designed to work with a big IBM mainframe called the System/390. This machine, which first came out in 1986, could handle up to 60 phone lines at once, making it easier for many computers to communicate with each other. Think of it like a traffic controller for data!

The 3720 was a smaller, simpler version of another similar IBM product called the 3725. IBM stopped providing support for the 3720 in 1999, when they switched to using the 3745 instead.

It's important to note that this 3720 is different from another IBM product also numbered 3720, which was a display terminal used for showing information on screens. These two products serve very different purposes.

For more details, you can check out the IBM 3720 Communication Controller Service Guide, available as a PDF.

adult_technical.text:
The IBM 3720 was a communications controller, also known as a front-end processor, designed by IBM for integration with the IBM System/390 mainframe. Introduced in 1986, this device was capable of managing up to 60 communication lines, positioning it as a more compact alternative to the IBM 3725. Official support for the 3720 ceased in 1999, being supplanted by the IBM 3745.

It is important to note that the IBM 3720 should not be confused with the IBM 3270 display terminal system, which shares a similar model number but serves entirely different purposes.

For detailed technical information, refer to the IBM 3720 Communication Controller Service Guide (PDF).

samples.title: PhpWiki
samples.original_text:
PhpWiki is a web-based wiki software application.
It began as a clone of WikiWikiWeb and was the first wiki written in PHP.
PhpWiki has been used to edit and format paper books for publication.

History
The first version, by Steve Wainstead, was released in December 1999. It was the first Wiki written in PHP to be publicly released. This version required PHP 3.x and only supported DBM files. 
It was a feature-for-feature reimplementation of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000 Arno Hollosi added a second database library to allow running PhpWiki on MySQL.
From then on more features were added and contributions to the software increased, adding features such as a templating system, color diffs, rewrites of the rendering engine and much more. Arno was interested in running a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor, and soon headed the project for the next few years, followed up by Reini Urban up to 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since 1.5.

Releases 

With version 1.4.0 Wikicreole 1.0 including additions and MediaWiki markup syntax are supported. In version 1.5.0 PHP 4 support was deprecated.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4 et 5.5. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3.

Version 1.6.0 is compatible from PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3 with
ARIA roles.

Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

See also

 List of wiki software
 Comparison of wiki software

References

External links
 
 Release Notes

Cross-platform free software
Free wiki software
Free software programmed in PHP
Software clones

easy_general.text:
**What is PhpWiki?**

PhpWiki is a type of website where people can create and edit pages together. It started as a copy of another wiki called WikiWikiWeb and was one of the first wikis made using PHP, a programming language.

**History of PhpWiki**

- **1999:** Steve Wainstead created the first version of PhpWiki. It could only use a specific type of file called DBM and needed PHP 3.x to work.
- **2000:** Arno Hollosi added support for MySQL, a different kind of database. More features were added over time, like a way to change page colors and compare changes.

- **2000-2014:** Jeff Dairiki became the main developer and led the project for several years. Reini Urban took over until version 1.4, and Marc-Etienne Vargenau has been in charge since version 1.5.

**Features of PhpWiki**

- **Wikicreole 1.0 (Version 1.4.0):** Added support for special formatting codes and MediaWiki's markup language.
- **PHP 4 Deprecation (Version 1.5.0):** Stopped supporting older versions of PHP.
- **PHP 5 Compatibility (Version 1.5.x):** Worked well with newer versions of PHP 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5, and generated code in HTML5 and CSS3.
- **PHP 8 Compatibility (Version 1.6.0):** Updated to work with even newer versions of PHP, including PHP 8.0, and continued to generate code in HTML5 and CSS3 with ARIA roles.
- **PHP 8.1 Compatibility (Version 1.6.1):** Further updated to work with PHP 8.1.

**More Information**

For more details about other wiki software or to learn how to use PhpWiki, check out these resources:

- **List of Wiki Software**
- **Comparison of Wiki Software**

For additional information, see the release notes and external links provided.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Introduction to PhpWiki**

PhpWiki is a type of software that lets people create and edit web pages collaboratively. It started as a copy of another wiki called WikiWikiWeb and was one of the first wikis built using PHP, a programming language that helps make websites interactive.

**History**

The very first version of PhpWiki was created by Steve Wainstead in December 1999. It was special because it was the first PHP-based wiki to be shared with the public. This early version needed PHP 3.x and could only work with something called DBM files. It was designed to be just like the original WikiWikiWeb found on a website called c2.com.

In early 2000, Arno Hollosi added support for MySQL, which is a different way to store data. After that, more features were added, and people started contributing to the software. These updates included things like a system for organizing content (called a templating system), showing changes in colors (color diffs), and rewriting how the pages look when they're displayed (the rendering engine). Arno was particularly interested in using PhpWiki for a game called Go.

Jeff Dairiki became a key contributor and led the project for several years. He was followed by Reini Urban until version 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau took over starting with version 1.5.

**Key Features and Versions**

- **Version 1.4.0**: Added support for Wikicreole 1.0 and MediaWiki markup syntax. MediaWiki is another popular wiki platform.
- **Version 1.5.0**: No longer supported PHP 4, which was an older version of the PHP programming language.
- **Version 1.5.x**: Compatible with newer versions of PHP, specifically 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5. The code was made to look modern using HTML5 and CSS3.
- **Version 1.6.0**: Compatible with even newer versions of PHP, from 5.3.3 to 8.0. It continued to use HTML5 and CSS3, and introduced something called ARIA roles, which help make web pages easier to navigate for people who use screen readers.
- **Version 1.6.1**: Added support for PHP 8.1.

**More Information**

For those interested in learning more about other wiki software or comparing different options, there are lists and comparisons available

adult_technical.text:
PHPWiki is a web-based wiki software application that originated as a clone of WikiWikiWeb and was the pioneering wiki developed using PHP. It has been utilized for editing and formatting content for publication, including paper books.

### History

The initial version, authored by Steve Wainstead, was released in December 1999, marking the first public release of a PHP-based wiki. This version required PHP 3.x and supported DBM files exclusively, serving as a feature-for-feature reimplementation of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000, Arno Hollosi enhanced PHPWiki by integrating a second database library, enabling its operation on MySQL. Following this, the project saw continuous development, with new features being added and contributions increasing. Notable additions included a templating system, color diffs, and a rewritten rendering engine. Arno's primary interest was in deploying a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki became the next significant contributor and led the project for several years. He was succeeded by Reini Urban until version 1.4, after which Marc-Etienne Vargenau took over starting from version 1.5.

### Releases

- **Version 1.4.0** (2007) introduced support for Wikicreole 1.0 and MediaWiki markup syntax. PHP 4 support was deprecated in this version.
- **Version 1.5.0** (2008) marked the deprecation of PHP 4 support and ensured compatibility with PHP 5.3, 5.4, and 5.5. The code generation was updated to HTML5 and CSS3.
- **Version 1.6.0** (2015) expanded compatibility to PHP versions from 5.3.3 to 8.0, maintaining HTML5 and CSS3 code generation with ARIA roles.
- **Version 1.6.1** (2016) added support for PHP 8.1.

### References

For further information, see:

- **List of wiki software**
- **Comparison of wiki software**

### External Links

- **Release Notes**
- **Cross-platform free software**
- **Free wiki software**
- **Free software programmed in PHP**

samples.title: Wohpe
samples.original_text:
In Lakota mythology, Wóȟpe (less correctly spelled "Wohpe") is a spirit of peace, the daughter of Wi and the Moon, Haŋhépi-Wi. She is the wife of the south wind. When she visited the Earth, she gave the Lakota people a pipe as a symbol of peace. Later, Wóȟpe became conflated with White Buffalo Calf Woman. An alternative name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ. 

As a symbol of Wophe's coming to earth she is often associated with falling stars.

See also
Dignity (statue)

Lakota spirit beings
Peace goddesses
Lakota culture

easy_general.text:
In Lakota mythology, there is a spirit named Wóȟpe (also spelled Wohpe). She represents peace and is the daughter of Wi, who is a god, and Haŋhépi-Wi, who is the Moon. Wóȟpe is married to the South Wind. When she came to Earth, she gave the Lakota people a special pipe as a sign of peace.

Later, Wóȟpe was sometimes confused with another important figure called White Buffalo Calf Woman. Another name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ.

Wóȟpe is often linked to falling stars, which are like bright lights in the sky that suddenly appear and disappear quickly.

For more information, see:
- Dignity (a statue)
- Other spirit beings in Lakota stories
- Goddesses who represent peace
- Information about Lakota culture

This helps us understand the role of Wóȟpe in Lakota beliefs and how she is connected to peace and the natural world.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Lakota mythology, there’s a spirit named Wóȟpe, sometimes spelled as Wohpe. She represents peace and is the daughter of Wi, who is the god of the sun, and Haŋhépi-Wi, the moon. Wóȟpe is married to the South Wind. One day, she came to Earth and gifted the Lakota people a special pipe as a symbol of peace.

Over time, Wóȟpe was often confused with another important figure called White Buffalo Calf Woman. Another name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ.

When Wóȟpe visits Earth, she is often linked to falling stars, which are meteors in scientific terms.

For more information, you might want to look at statues representing dignity or learn about other spirit beings in Lakota mythology. Additionally, understanding peace goddesses and exploring Lakota culture can give you a deeper insight into these beliefs.

adult_technical.text:
In Lakota mythology, Wóȟpe (also spelled Wohpe) is a spirit of peace, the daughter of Wi, the god of thunder, and Haŋhépi-Wi, the Moon. She is wed to the South Wind. Upon her visit to Earth, Wóȟpe presented the Lakota people with a peace pipe as a symbolic gesture. Over time, Wóȟpe was conflated with White Buffalo Calf Woman. An alternative name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ.

Wóȟpe's arrival on Earth is often symbolized by falling stars. This celestial phenomenon is frequently invoked in Lakota narratives to signify her presence or visitation.

For further reading, see:
- Dignity (statue)
- Other Lakota spirit beings
- Peace goddesses in various cultures
- Lakota cultural traditions and beliefs

samples.title: Arthur J. Stone
samples.original_text:
Arthur J. Stone (1847–1938), a leading American silversmith, was born, trained and worked in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland, before travelling to the United States in 1884. He was one of the last silversmiths in America to train apprentices to carry out designs in hand-wrought silver. In 1901, Stone set up a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts which operated under his name until its sale in 1937 to Henry Heywood. Heywood was a Gardner businessman, who renamed it The Stone Silver Shop, and later, Stone Associates. Heywood died in 1945. His sons Henry, Jr. and Jerome ran Stone Associates until 1957.

One of the silversmiths in Arthur Stone's shop was George Porter Blanchard, father of silversmith Porter Blanchard.

References

External links

Work examples and makers' marks
Samples of his work
Samples of his work
Article on Stone silver
Notes on his career and a picture of him at work
