easy_general.text:
Arthur J. Stone, an important American silversmith, was born in 1847 and grew up in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland. He moved to the United States in 1884. Stone was one of the last silversmiths in America to teach young people how to make designs using hand-wrought silver. 

In 1901, he opened a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts. This workshop was called "Stone" until 1937, when it was sold to Henry Heywood. Heywood changed the name to "The Stone Silver Shop" and later to "Stone Associates." Henry Heywood passed away in 1945. His sons, Henry Jr. and Jerome, managed the business until 1957.

One of the workers at Stone's workshop was George Porter Blanchard, whose son became a silversmith named Porter Blanchard.

Some of Stone's work can be seen online. There are also notes about his life and a picture of him working.

Important dates:
- Born in 1847
- Died in 1938
- Came from Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland
- Opened a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts in 1901
- Sold his workshop in 1937
- His sons managed the business after his death until 1957

Stone was known as an American silversmith who learned his craft in England and Scotland before moving to the United States.

adult_non_technical.text:
Arthur J. Stone (1847–1938) was a famous American silversmith who learned his craft in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland. He moved to the United States in 1884 and became one of the last silversmiths in America to teach apprentices how to create designs using hand-wrought silver. In 1901, he opened a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts, where he worked until 1937. The workshop was then sold to Henry Heywood, a local businessman. Heywood kept the name "Stone Silver Shop" and later changed it to "Stone Associates." Henry Heywood passed away in 1945, and his sons, Henry Jr. and Jerome, continued running the business until 1957.

One of the apprentices at Stone’s workshop was George Porter Blanchard, whose son, Porter Blanchard, also became a silversmith.

You can find more about Stone's work and see samples of his creations through external links provided. There are articles and notes about his career as well, including a picture of him at work.

Some key points to remember:
- Stone was born in 1847 and died in 1938.
- He was an American silversmith who originally trained in England and Scotland.
- He taught apprentices to make silver items by hand.
- His workshop in Massachusetts operated from 1901 to 1937.
- It was later run by Henry Heywood and his sons until 1957.
- One of his apprentices, George Porter Blanchard, had a son who also became a silversmith.

adult_technical.text:
Arthur J. Stone (1847–1938) was a prominent American silversmith who was born, trained, and worked in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland, before immigrating to the United States in 1884. Known for his traditional craftsmanship, Stone was among the last American silversmiths to apprentice artisans in the art of hand-wrought silver design. In 1901, he established a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts, which continued to operate under his name until its acquisition by Henry Heywood in 1937. Heywood, a local businessman, renamed the establishment The Stone Silver Shop and later, Stone Associates. Heywood passed away in 1945, leaving the business to his sons, Henry, Jr., and Jerome, who managed Stone Associates until 1957.

Among the artisans employed by Stone was George Porter Blanchard, the father of renowned silversmith Porter Blanchard.

samples.title: South Manheim Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
South Manheim Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 2,191 at the 2000 census. It was created in 1845 by dividing Manheim Township into South Manheim and North Manheim Townships.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.0 square miles (54.3 km), of which, 20.6 square miles (53.3 km) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.0 km) of it (1.77%) is water.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 2,191 people, 796 households, and 643 families living in the township.  The population density was 106.4 people per square mile (41.1/km).  There were 966 housing units at an average density of 46.9/sq mi (18.1/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.31% White, 0.46% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.37% from other races, and 0.64% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.68%.

Of the 796 households 35.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.0% were married couples living together, 5.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 14.9% of households were one person and 6.3% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.07.

The age distribution was 25.9% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 29.8% from 25 to 44, 25.8% from 45 to 64, and 13.1% 65 or older.  The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.9 males.

The median household income was $46,786 and the median family income  was $49,757. Males had a median income of $37,629 versus $26,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $19,638.  About 2.0% of families and 3.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 2.2% of those under age 18 and 4.5% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
Townships in Pennsylvania

samples.title: 690s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 699 BC – 690 BC.

Events and trends
 699 BC—Khallushu succeeds Shuttir-Nakhkhunte as king of the Elamite Empire.
 697 BC—Birth of Duke Wen of Jin in China.
 697 BC—Death of King Huan of Zhou in China.
 697 BC—Hezekiah succeeded by Manasseh as king of Judah.
 696 BC—King Zhuang of Zhou begins his reign in China.
 696 BC—The Cimmerians ravage Phrygia, possible migration of the Armenians.
 696 BC—Pantacles of Athens wins the stadion race at the 21st Olympic Games.
 692 BC—Karib'il Watar of Saba' is recorded as having given "gifts" (tribute) to King Sennacherib of Assyria.
 692 BC—Pantacles wins the stadion race for a second time and the diaulos at the 22nd Olympic Games.
 691 BC—King Sennacherib of Assyria defeats king Humban-nimena of Elam in the Battle of Halule.
 690 BC—Taharqa, a king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, ascends the throne of Egypt (approximate date)
  690 BC-664 BC—Sphinx of Taharqa, from Temple T, Kawa, Nubia, is made. Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. It is now kept at The British Museum, London.
 c. 690 BC—Death of Manava, author of the Indian geometric text of Sulba Sutras.
 690s BC—W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia appears in the inscriptional record and mentions the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

Significant people

References

easy_general.text:
This article covers events and trends from 699 BC to 690 BC.

### Events and Trends

- **699 BC**: Khallushu becomes the new king of the Elamite Empire after Shuttir-Nakhkhunte.
- **697 BC**: Duke Wen of Jin is born in China.
- **697 BC**: King Huan of Zhou dies in China.
- **697 BC**: Hezekiah becomes king of Judah after being succeeded by Manasseh.
- **696 BC**: King Zhuang of Zhou starts his rule in China.
- **696 BC**: The Cimmerians attack Phrygia, which might have led to the movement of the Armenians.
- **696 BC**: A man named Pantacles wins a footrace at the 21st Olympic Games in Athens.
- **692 BC**: King Sennacherib of Assyria receives gifts from Karib'il Watar of Saba'.
- **692 BC**: Pantacles wins another footrace and a longer race at the 22nd Olympic Games.
- **691 BC**: King Sennacherib of Assyria defeats King Humban-nimena of Elam in a battle.
- **690 BC**: Taharqa, a king from the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, becomes the ruler of Egypt (around this time).
- **690–664 BC**: A statue of Taharqa, known as the Sphinx of Taharqa, is made in Nubia and is now in the British Museum in London.
- **Around 690 BC**: Manava, who wrote an ancient Indian math book called Sulba Sutras, dies.
- **690s BC**: W'rn Hywt, a leader from D'mt in Ethiopia, is mentioned in inscriptions and talks about the king of Saba'.

### Significant People

The article also mentions some important people from this period.

adult_non_technical.text:
This article covers events and trends from 699 BC to 690 BC, a fascinating period in ancient history.

### Key Events and Trends

- **699 BC**: Khallushu takes over as the king of Elam, a powerful empire in what is now Iran.
- **697 BC**: In China, Duke Wen of Jin is born, while King Huan of Zhou passes away. Meanwhile, Hezekiah becomes king of Judah, succeeding Manasseh.
- **696 BC**: King Zhuang of Zhou starts his rule in China. The Cimmerians, a group of warriors, attack Phrygia, which might have led to the movement of the Armenians. Pantacles, an athlete from Athens, wins a footrace at the Olympics for the first time.
- **692 BC**: King Sennacherib of Assyria, a powerful ruler in what is now Iraq, receives gifts from Karib'il Watar of Saba', another kingdom. Pantacles wins another footrace and a longer race at the Olympics.
- **691 BC**: King Sennacherib defeats King Humban-nimena of Elam in a major battle.
- **690 BC**: Taharqa, a king from a dynasty in Egypt, becomes the new pharaoh. Around this time, a statue of Taharqa is carved in Nubia, in modern-day Sudan, and is now housed in the British Museum in London.
- **Around 690 BC**: Manava, who wrote an important book on geometry in India, dies.
- **690s BC**: W'rn Hywt, a leader from a region called D'mt in Ethiopia, is mentioned in inscriptions, noting the king of Saba'.

### Significant People

The article also highlights several key figures from this era, including Khallushu, King Sennacherib, King Huan of Zhou, Hezekiah, Manasseh, King Zhuang of Zhou, Karib'il Watar, Taharqa, and Manava.

These events paint a picture of a time when empires rose and fell, kings and queens ruled, and great athletes and thinkers made their mark on history.

adult_technical.text:
This article covers the historical period from 699 BC to 690 BC, highlighting key events and trends during this interval.

### Events and Trends

**699 BC:** Khallushu succeeded Shuttir-Nakhkhunte as the king of the Elamite Empire.

**697 BC:** 
- Birth of Duke Wen of Jin in China.
- Death of King Huan of Zhou in China.
- Hezekiah was succeeded by Manasseh as king of Judah.
- King Zhuang of Zhou began his reign in China.
- The Cimmerians launched a raid against Phrygia, potentially leading to the migration of the Armenians.
- Pantacles of Athens won the stadion race at the 21st Olympic Games.

**696 BC:** 
- Pantacles won the stadion race for a second time and the diaulos event at the 22nd Olympic Games.
- King Zhuang of Zhou commenced his rule in China.
- The Cimmerians ravaged Phrygia again, possibly contributing to the Armenian migration.
- Pantacles of Athens won the stadion race at the 22nd Olympic Games.

**692 BC:** 
- Karib'il Watar of Saba' is documented as having provided tribute to King Sennacherib of Assyria.
- Karib'il Watar of Saba' again presented gifts to King Sennacherib of Assyria.

**691 BC:** 
- King Sennacherib of Assyria defeated King Humban-nimena of Elam in the Battle of Halule.

**690 BC:** 
- Taharqa, a ruler of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, ascended to the throne of Egypt (approximate date).
- The Sphinx of Taharqa, from Temple T in Kawa, Nubia, was created during the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. This artifact is currently housed at the British Museum in London.
- Manava, the author of the Indian geometric text Sulba Sutras, died around this time.

**690s BC:** 
- W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia appeared in the inscriptional record and mentioned the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

### Significant People

References to notable individuals and their contributions during this period are included.

samples.title: Essunga Municipality
samples.original_text:
Essunga Municipality (Essunga kommun) is a municipality in Västra Götaland County in western Sweden. Its seat is located in the town of Nossebro.

The 1952 municipal reform in Sweden saw the creation of Essunga Municipality out of eight original entities. In 1974 it was dissolved and part of Vara Municipality until 1983, when it was reestablished within the boundaries of 1952. The village of Essunga is a minor settlement just east of Nossebro.

References

External links
 
Essunga Municipality - Official site

Municipalities of Västra Götaland County
Skaraborg

easy_general.text:
Essunga Municipality is a place in western Sweden, in an area called Västra Götaland County. Its main town is Nossebro.

In 1952, Sweden made changes to its municipalities. Essunga Municipality was created from eight smaller areas. In 1974, Essunga became part of another town called Vara. But in 1983, Essunga came back as its own municipality again.

There's a small village named Essunga, which is close to Nossebro but not very big.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Essunga Municipality. You can also learn about other towns in Västra Götaland County.

adult_non_technical.text:
Essunga Municipality is a local government area in western Sweden, specifically in Västra Götaland County. Its main office is in the town of Nossebro.

In 1952, Sweden made changes to its local government system. As part of this change, Essunga Municipality was formed from eight smaller areas. For about a decade, starting in 1974, Essunga became part of another municipality called Vara. But in 1983, Essunga was brought back as a separate municipality, with the same borders as it had in 1952.

There's a small village called Essunga, which is just east of Nossebro.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Essunga Municipality. You might also want to check out a list of all municipalities in Västra Götaland County, including Skaraborg.

adult_technical.text:
Essunga Municipality (Essunga kommun) is a Swedish administrative unit situated in Västra Götaland County, located in western Sweden. Its administrative center is the town of Nossebro.

In 1952, as part of a comprehensive municipal reform in Sweden, Essunga Municipality was established from eight original administrative units. Between 1974 and 1983, it was briefly dissolved and incorporated into Vara Municipality. However, in 1983, it was reconstituted within its 1952 boundaries. Notably, the village of Essunga, which lies just east of Nossebro, is a minor settlement within the municipality.

For further information, refer to the official website of Essunga Municipality or explore the list of municipalities in Västra Götaland County, including Skaraborg.

samples.title: Thematic role
samples.original_text:
Thematic role is a linguistic notion, which may refer to:

 Theta role (in syntax or at the syntax-semantics interface), the formal device for representing syntactic argument structure—the number and type of noun phrases—required syntactically by a particular verb
 Thematic relation (in semantics), a term to express the role that a noun phrase plays with respect to the action or state described by a governing verb

easy_general.text:
Thematic role is a concept used in language studies. It helps us understand how different parts of a sentence work together.

In simple terms, a theta role is like a job description for words in a sentence. When we use a verb, it needs certain types of nouns to complete its meaning. For example, if we say "The dog chased," "dog" has a specific role—it's the one doing the chasing. This role is called a theta role because it tells us what kind of noun phrase the verb needs.

A thematic relation is another way to describe how a noun phrase fits into the action or state described by a verb. For instance, in "The cat sat on the mat," "cat" is the one performing the action of sitting. So, "cat" has a thematic relation to the verb "sat." This relation helps us understand the connection between the subject and the action in a sentence.

adult_non_technical.text:
In simple terms, thematic roles are about how different parts of a sentence work together when we talk about actions or states. Let's break this down into two main ideas:

1. **Theta Role**: This is like a set of instructions for a verb. When you use a verb, it needs certain types of information to make sense. For example, if you say "run," you need to know who is running. The theta role tells us what kind of information (like a person or thing) a verb needs. In grammar, we call these pieces of information "noun phrases."

2. **Thematic Relation**: This is about how the nouns in a sentence relate to the action or state being described. It’s like asking, "Who or what is doing the action?" or "What is affected by the action?" For instance, in the sentence "The cat chased the mouse," "the cat" is doing the chasing, and "the mouse" is being chased. These roles help us understand who is involved in the action.

Both of these concepts help us understand how words in a sentence fit together to describe actions or states clearly.

adult_technical.text:
Thematic role is a linguistic concept that encompasses two related but distinct aspects of verbal semantics and syntax:

1. **Theta Role**: This is a formal construct used in syntactic analysis to represent the syntactic argument structure required by a specific verb. It specifies the number and type of noun phrases (NPs) that a verb demands as its arguments. For instance, a transitive verb like "hit" requires one NP as the agent and another as the patient, thus having two theta roles.

2. **Thematic Relation**: In the domain of semantics, this term denotes the semantic role that a noun phrase plays relative to the action or state described by the governing verb. It describes how the participants in a sentence relate to the event or process being described. For example, in the sentence "John hit the ball," "John" has the thematic relation of agent, and "the ball" has the thematic relation of patient.

These two concepts, while often used interchangeably in casual discourse, serve different purposes in linguistic analysis. Theta role focuses on the syntactic requirements of verbs, whereas thematic relation emphasizes the semantic interpretation of those roles within the context of the sentence.

samples.title: Windsor Township, Traverse County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Windsor Township is a township in Traverse County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 54 at the 2000 census.

History
Windsor Township was organized in 1881.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.8 square miles (56.4 km), of which 15.7 square miles (40.6 km) is land and 6.1 square miles (15.8 km) (28.04%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 54 people, 23 households, and 18 families residing in the township. The population density was 3.4 people per square mile (1.3/km). There were 147 housing units at an average density of 9.4/sq mi (3.6/km). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 23 households, out of which 30.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 73.9% were married couples living together, and 21.7% were non-families. 21.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.35 and the average family size was 2.72.

In the township the population was spread out, with 24.1% under the age of 18, 1.9% from 18 to 24, 24.1% from 25 to 44, 29.6% from 45 to 64, and 20.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 45 years. For every 100 females, there were 125.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 127.8 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $26,250, and the median income for a family was $26,250. Males had a median income of $26,250 versus $6,250 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,582. There were 9.1% of families and 6.8% of the population living below the poverty line, including 22.2% of under eighteens and none of those over 64.

References

Townships in Traverse County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

easy_general.text:
Windsor Township is a small area in Traverse County, Minnesota, United States. In the year 2000, it had 54 people living there.

History
Windsor Township was set up in 1881.

Geography
Windsor Township covers about 21.8 square miles (which is like 56 football fields). Most of this is land, but about 28% is water, like lakes or rivers.

Demographics
In 2000, there were 54 people, 23 families, and 18 households. On average, there were only 3.4 people per square mile. There were 147 houses, with an average of 9.4 houses per square mile. Everyone there was white.

Households
Out of the 23 households, about 30% had kids under 18. About 74% were married couples, and 22% were single people living alone. None of the households had elderly people living alone.

Age Distribution
About 24% of the people were under 18, 24% were between 25 and 44, 29% were between 45 and 64, and 20% were 65 or older. The average age was 45.

Gender Balance
For every 100 women, there were 125 men. For every 100 women over 18, there were 128 men.

Income
The average income for a household and a family was $26,250. Men earned the same amount as women, but women earned less. The money each person earned on average was $15,582. About 9% of families and 7% of the population lived below the poverty line. This included 22% of people under 18, but no one over 64.

References
This information is about townships in Traverse County, Minnesota, and all townships in Minnesota.

samples.title: L'inglesou
samples.original_text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou loa who lives in the wild areas of Haiti and kills anyone who offends him.

Portrayal
He executes judgment on those who can't keep their word, including houngans and mamboes who can't keep the secrets of voodoo from the uninitiated. L'inglesou is feared and respected by all. He almost never comes in possession, but when he does, he must be served correctly; otherwise the houngan or mambo will be cruelly punished.

When L'inglesou comes in possession, he only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red. He is syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects such as knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and, in general, anything that will rip or tear flesh.

References

Haitian Vodou gods

easy_general.text:
L'inglesou is a spirit in Haitian Vodou who lives in wild areas and punishes people who upset him.

What L'inglesou Does
L'inglesou judges people who break promises, even important religious leaders like houngans (priests) and mamboes (priestesses). These leaders must keep secret knowledge about Vodou from others. Everyone fears and respects L'inglesou because of his power.

How L'inglesou Appears
L'inglesou rarely takes control of someone's body, but when he does, it's important to treat him properly. If not, the person controlling L'inglesou might suffer harsh punishment.

What L'inglesou Eats and Drinks
When L'inglesou does take control, he only eats glass and razor blades and drinks warm blood from bulls. His favorite color is red. He is also connected to the Sacred Heart of Jesus in some beliefs.

Things L'inglesou Likes
L'inglesou enjoys sharp things that can cut or tear skin, like knives, scissors, barbed wire, and razor blades.

This information comes from books about Haitian Vodou gods.

adult_non_technical.text:
L'inglesou is a spirit in Haitian Vodou who resides in the wild parts of Haiti. This spirit is known for punishing people who upset him, much like how a parent might punish a child for misbehaving.

Role and Impact
L'inglesou is feared and respected by everyone, even the priests and priestesses (called houngans and mamboes) who perform rituals. He enforces strict rules, especially about keeping secrets. If someone breaks these rules, they risk his wrath. Even the most trusted religious leaders can face severe consequences if they fail to protect the secrets of Vodou.

Appearance and Behavior
When L'inglesou appears, he has a distinctive appearance. He is often seen as red, which is a common color associated with powerful spirits. He prefers to eat unusual things like glass and razor blades and drink warm blood from bulls. Unlike some other spirits, L'inglesou doesn’t usually take over people's bodies, but when he does, it’s crucial to treat him properly. Otherwise, the person who invoked him could suffer harsh penalties.

Preferences
L'inglesou has a particular liking for sharp objects. He enjoys items that can cut or tear, such as knives, scissors, barbed wire, and razor blades. These objects symbolize his power and the potential for harm he represents.

In Summary
L'inglesou is a significant figure in Haitian Vodou, known for his strict rules and his ability to cause punishment. He is both feared and respected, and his presence is marked by unusual and sometimes dangerous behaviors.

adult_technical.text:
L'Ingèsou is a Vodou loa associated with the wild regions of Haiti, known for exacting retribution upon those who offend him. This loa is particularly vigilant against individuals who breach sacred oaths, including houngans (Vodou priests) and mamboes (Vodou priestesses), who are entrusted with maintaining the confidentiality of Vodou rituals and practices. L'Ingèsou is both revered and feared within the Vodou community.

L'Ingèsou's domain extends to enforcing the sanctity of oaths and secrets, ensuring that those who violate these sacred tenets face severe consequences. While he rarely possesses individuals, when he does, proper respect and service must be rendered; failure to do so would result in harsh punishment for the houngan or mambo.

During possession by L'Ingèsou, the individual exhibits a unique set of behaviors and preferences. L'Ingèsou consumes only glass and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. The loa's color is red, and he is often syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. L'Ingèsou has a particular affinity for sharp objects, including knives, scissors, barbed wire, and any items capable of inflicting tearing or cutting injuries.

For a deeper understanding of L'Ingèsou and other Haitian Vodou deities, refer to scholarly works on Haitian Vodou.

samples.title: Fairlight
samples.original_text:
Fairlight may refer to:

In places:
 Fairlight, East Sussex, a village east of Hastings in southern England, UK
 Fairlight Primary and Nursery School, a primary school in Brighton, England
 Fairlight, New South Wales, a suburb of Sydney, Australia
 Fairlight, Saskatchewan, Canada

In other uses:
 Fairlight (company), an Australian producer of synthesizers then digital audio tools
 Fairlight CMI, the first digital sampling synthesiser
 Fairlight (group), a Commodore 64, Amiga and PC demo group, as well as a warez group
 Fairlight (video game), a computer game by Bo Jangeborg, published by The Edge
 Fairlight (ferry), a Sydney to Manly ferry that operated between 1878 and 1914

See also
 Fairlight Cove, a small village on the East Sussex coast
 Fairlight Glen, a nudist beach on the East Sussex coast

easy_general.text:
Fairlight can mean different things:

In places:
- Fairlight, a village in East Sussex, England. It's near Hastings in the south of England.
- Fairlight Primary and Nursery School, a school in Brighton, England.
- Fairlight, a neighborhood in Sydney, Australia.
- Fairlight, a place in Saskatchewan, Canada.

In other uses:
- Fairlight (company): An Australian company that made music tools like synthesizers and digital audio equipment.
- Fairlight CMI: This was the first machine that could record sounds and play them back as music.
- Fairlight (group): A group that made computer games and software for Commodore 64, Amiga, and PC computers.
- Fairlight (video game): A computer game made by Bo Jangeborg and published by The Edge.
- Fairlight (ferry): A boat that used to run between Sydney and Manly from 1878 to 1914.

Also see:
- Fairlight Cove: A small village on the coast of East Sussex.
- Fairlight Glen: A nudist beach on the coast of East Sussex.

adult_non_technical.text:
Fairlight can mean different things depending on where you look:

In places:
- Fairlight, a small village in East Sussex, England, which is near Hastings.
- Fairlight Primary and Nursery School, a school in Brighton, England.
- Fairlight, a neighborhood in Sydney, Australia.
- Fairlight, a place in Saskatchewan, Canada.

In other uses:
- Fairlight (company): An Australian company that made special music tools like synthesizers and digital audio equipment.
- Fairlight CMI: This was the very first device that could record sounds and play them back as part of music, kind of like a digital music box.
- Fairlight (groups): A team of people who create cool computer programs and games, and sometimes they share software that isn't officially allowed.
- Fairlight (game): A fun computer game made by someone named Bo Jangeborg, published by another company called The Edge.
- Fairlight (ferry): A boat that used to take people from Sydney to a nearby beach town called Manly, operating from 1878 to 1914.

Also worth mentioning:
- Fairlight Cove: A small village along the coast of East Sussex.
- Fairlight Glen: A special beach in East Sussex where people go without clothes.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Fairlight" can denote multiple entities across different contexts:

Geographical Locations:
- Fairlight, East Sussex, United Kingdom: A village situated east of Hastings in southern England.
- Fairlight Primary and Nursery School: A primary educational institution located in Brighton, England.
- Fairlight, New South Wales, Australia: A suburb within the greater Sydney area.
- Fairlight, Saskatchewan, Canada: A locality within the province of Saskatchewan.

Technical and Cultural References:
- Fairlight (company): An Australian firm renowned for its pioneering work in synthesizers and digital audio tools.
- Fairlight CMI: The inaugural digital sampling synthesizer, marking a significant milestone in electronic music technology.
- Fairlight (group): Refers to two distinct groups—firstly, a Commodore 64, Amiga, and PC demo collective, and secondly, a warez group.
- Fairlight (video game): A computer game developed by Bo Jangeborg and published by The Edge.
- Fairlight (ferry): A historical vessel that operated the Sydney to Manly route from 1878 to 1914.

Additional Related Entries:
- Fairlight Cove: A small coastal village in East Sussex, United Kingdom.
- Fairlight Glen: A nudist beach located along the East Sussex coastline.

samples.title: Dornier
samples.original_text:
Dornier may refer to:
 Claudius Dornier (1884–1969), German aircraft designer and builder
 Dornier Flugzeugwerke, German aircraft manufacturer founded in 1914 by Claudius Dornier 
 Dornier Consulting, international consulting and project management company 
 Fairchild-Dornier, in 1996, Fairchild took on this name, when it purchased Dornier's assets, see Fairchild Aircraft
 Lindauer Dornier, German textile machinery manufacturer
 Dornier Wines, a winery in South Africa

See also
 
 List of military aircraft of Germany by manufacturer#Dornier

easy_general.text:
Dornier can mean different things:

- **Claudius Dornier (1884–1969)**: He was a German person who designed and built airplanes.
- **Dornier Flugzeugwerke**: This was a company in Germany that made airplanes. It was started by Claudius Dornier in 1914.
- **Dornier Consulting**: This is a big company that helps other companies with their projects and plans.
- **Fairchild-Dornier**: In 1996, a company called Fairchild bought parts of Dornier's business and changed its name to Fairchild-Dornier.
- **Lindauer Dornier**: This is a company in Germany that makes machines used in making textiles.
- **Dornier Wines**: This is a winery, or place where wine is made, in South Africa.

For more information about airplanes made in Germany, check out the list of military aircraft made by German companies, which includes Dornier.

adult_non_technical.text:
Dornier is a name that has been used in various industries over the years:

- **Claudius Dornier (1884–1969)**: He was a German engineer who designed and built airplanes. Think of him as the inventor who created the first Dornier planes.

- **Dornier Flugzeugwerke**: This is a German company that makes airplanes. It was started in 1914 by Claudius Dornier, the same person who designed those early planes. "Flugzeugwerke" means "aircraft works" in German.

- **Dornier Consulting**: This is a big company that helps other businesses with planning and managing projects. They offer advice and solutions to make sure projects run smoothly.

- **Fairchild-Dornier**: In 1996, a company called Fairchild bought parts of Dornier's business and decided to use the Dornier name. So, Fairchild-Dornier became a new company that combined Fairchild's technology with Dornier's legacy.

- **Lindauer Dornier**: This is another German company that makes machines for making textiles, like fabric and clothing.

- **Dornier Wines**: This is a winery located in South Africa, where they grow grapes and make wine.

If you want to learn more about the airplanes made by Dornier, there’s a list of military aircraft made in Germany that includes Dornier models.

adult_technical.text:
Dornier is a multifaceted name associated with various entities in the aerospace and related industries:

1. **Claudius Dornier (1884–1969)**: A prominent German aircraft designer and manufacturer who played a significant role in the development of early aircraft technology.

2. **Dornier Flugzeugwerke**: Founded in 1914 by Claudius Dornier, this was a major German aircraft manufacturer that contributed significantly to both civilian and military aviation during the early 20th century.

3. **Dornier Consulting**: An international consulting and project management firm operating in multiple sectors, unrelated to the aerospace industry.

4. **Fairchild-Dornier**: This entity emerged in 1996 following the acquisition of Dornier's assets by Fairchild Industries, resulting in the formation of a new aerospace company.

5. **Lindauer Dornier**: A German manufacturer specializing in textile machinery, distinct from the aerospace sector.

6. **Dornier Wines**: A South African winery, unrelated to any aerospace or manufacturing activities.

For further reference, see the list of military aircraft of Germany by manufacturer, which includes entries under Dornier.

Demographics
At the 2000 census there were 5,677 people, 2,265 households, and 1,701 families living in the township.  The population density was 420.4 people per square mile (162.4/km2).  There were 2,344 housing units at an average density of 173.6/sq mi (67.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.26% White, 1.09% African American, 0.05% Native American, 0.11% Asian, 0.05% Pacific Islander, 0.21% from other races, and 0.23% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.74%.

Of the 2,265 households 26.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.4% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.9% were non-families. 22.3% of households were one person and 13.2% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.45 and the average family size was 2.85.

The age distribution was 19.6% under the age of 18, 4.9% from 18 to 24, 24.1% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 24.7% 65 or older.  The median age was 46 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.7 males.

The median household income was $43,347 and the median family income  was $52,526. Males had a median income of $40,970 versus $24,698 for females. The per capita income for the township was $20,380.  About 4.8% of families and 6.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 6.8% of those under age 18 and 8.9% of those age 65 or over.

Cedarville is a former city in Pike County, Kentucky, United States. The population was 52 at the 2000 census. On December 14, 2009, Cedarville became a part of Elkhorn City.

Geography
Cedarville is located at  (37.314057, -82.360233).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 52 people, 24 households, and 16 families residing in the city. The population density was 808.3 people per square mile (334.6/km2). There were 29 housing units at an average density of 450.8/sq mi (186.6/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 100.00% White. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 9.62% of the population.

There were 24 households, out of which 25.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were married couples living together, 4.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 33.3% were non-families. 29.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 25.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.17 and the average family size was 2.69.

In the city the population was spread out, with 17.3% under the age of 18, 5.8% from 18 to 24, 28.8% from 25 to 44, 25.0% from 45 to 64, and 23.1% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 108.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 104.8 males.

The median income for a household in the city was $46,500, and the median income for a family was $50,125. Males had a median income of $50,375 versus $0 for females. The per capita income for the city was $21,045. None of the population and none of the families were below the poverty line.

samples.title: Skarsterlân
samples.original_text:
Skarsterlân (;  ) is a former municipality in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands. The municipality was created 1 January 1984 by merging the municipalities of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, the part of Utingeradeel consisting of the villages Akmarijp and Terkaple and the village Nieuwebrug that used to belong to Heerenveen. City hall was located in Joure. On 1 January 2014 it merged with the municipalities of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form the new municipality De Fryske Marren.

At first, the Dutch name Scharsterland was chosen, but as of 1 March 1985, the West Frisian name Skarsterlân was adopted and the Dutch name became obsolete.

Population centres 

Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast and Vegelinsoord.

adult_technical.text:
Skarsterlân (West Frisian: Skarsterlân) was a former municipality located in the province of Friesland, Netherlands. Established on January 1, 1984, through the merger of the municipalities of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, along with parts of Utingeradeel comprising the villages of Akmarijp and Terkaple, and the village of Nieuwebrug formerly belonging to Heerenveen, Skarsterlân initially had its city hall in Joure. On January 1, 2014, it amalgamated with the municipalities of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form the new municipality De Fryske Marren.

Initially, the Dutch name Scharsterland was proposed, but effective March 1, 1985, the West Frisian name Skarsterlân was officially adopted, rendering the Dutch name obsolete.

**Population Centres**
The municipality included the following population centers: Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast, and Vegelinsoord.

samples.title: Iao
samples.original_text:
Iao may refer to:
 IAO (album), an album by avant jazz musician John Zorn
 Iao (Gnosticism), an archon corresponding to Jupiter
 Iao Theater, a theater in Wailuku, Hawaii
 Iao Valley, a tourist attraction in Maui, Hawaii
 Sayak Airport (IATA code: IAO), also known as Siargao Airport, in Surigao del Norte, Philippines
 , an early Greek form of the tetragrammaton, or name of God

IAO may stand for:

 Incorporated Association Of Organists
 Indian Astronomical Observatory, home of the highest telescope in the world
 Information Awareness Office, a branch of the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA)
 Interests, Activities, and Opinions - IAO or psychographic variables
 International Accreditation Organization (Houston, TX)
 International Academy of Osteopathy, an international school offering academic training in osteopathy
 International Astronomy Olympiad, an astronomy competition for high-school students
 Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy, an organization of parliamentarians of the Eastern Orthodox Church
 Institut d'Asie Orientale (Lyons Institute of East Asian Studies), a centre for research in human and social sciences at Université Lumière-Lyon 2 and Institut d'études politiques de Lyon
 Institute for Art and Olfaction, a non-profit organization
 Istituto agronomico per l'oltremare (Overseas Agronomic Institute), a technical and scientific body of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs

easy_general.text:
The term "IAO" can mean several different things:

1. **IAO (Album)**: This is an album made by a musician named John Zorn. He plays a type of music called avant-garde jazz.

2. **Iao (Gnosticism)**: In ancient beliefs, Iao was seen as a powerful being similar to Jupiter. Gnosticism is an old religious belief system.

3. **Iao Theater**: This is a theater located in Wailuku, Hawaii. It's a place where people go to watch plays and performances.

4. **Iao Valley**: This is a beautiful area in Maui, Hawaii, that tourists visit. It’s known for its natural beauty.

5. **Sayak Airport (IATA code: IAO)**: This airport is in a place called Siargao Island in the Philippines. It helps people travel to and from the island.

6. **Early Greek Form of Tetragrammaton**: This is an old way of writing the name of God in Greek. The tetragrammaton is the four-letter name of God used in the Hebrew Bible.

**IAO Can Also Mean:**

1. **Incorporated Association of Organists**: This is a group of people who play organs professionally.

2. **Indian Astronomical Observatory**: This is a special place in India where scientists study the stars and planets. It has the tallest telescope in the world.

3. **Information Awareness Office**: This is part of a big research group that works on keeping the country safe.

4. **Interests, Activities, and Opinions (IAO)**: This is a way to describe how people think and what they like.

5. **International Accreditation Organization**: This is a group based in Houston, Texas, that checks if schools and organizations meet certain standards.

6. **International Academy of Osteopathy**: This is a school that teaches people about a type of medicine called osteopathy.

7. **International Astronomy Olympiad**: This is a contest where high school students from all over the world compete in solving astronomy problems.

8. **Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy**: This is a group of people from different countries who work together to support Christian beliefs.

9. **Institut d'Asie Orientale**: This is a research center in France that studies Asian cultures and history.

10. **Institute for Art and Olfaction**: This is a nonprofit organization that studies smells and how they affect us.

1

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "IAO" can have several meanings depending on the context. Here’s what it might refer to:

1. **Music**: An album called "IAO" by a musician named John Zorn who plays avant-garde jazz.
2. **Religion**: In Gnosticism, IAO is a name for an archon (a lesser deity) that corresponds to Jupiter.
3. **Theater**: A theater called IAO located in Wailuku, Hawaii.
4. **Tourism**: IAO refers to Iao Valley, a scenic spot in Maui, Hawaii, where tourists often visit.
5. **Airports**: Sayak Airport, also known as Siargao Airport, is located in Surigao del Norte, Philippines. The airport's code is IAO.
6. **Ancient Religion**: It was also used in ancient Greece as a way to write the name of God.

In different fields, "IAO" stands for various organizations and concepts:

1. **Organizations for Musicians**: Incorporated Association of Organists.
2. **Astronomy**: Indian Astronomical Observatory, which houses the world's highest telescope.
3. **Government**: Information Awareness Office, part of the U.S. Defense Department.
4. **Psychology**: Interests, Activities, and Opinions (IAO), which are used to describe people's characteristics.
5. **Business**: International Accreditation Organization based in Houston, Texas.
6. **Education**: International Academy of Osteopathy, which teaches about osteopathy.
7. **Competitions**: International Astronomy Olympiad, a contest for high school students interested in astronomy.
8. **Churches**: Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy, a group of church leaders.
9. **Research Centers**: Institut d'Asie Orientale, a research center in France focused on East Asia.
10. **Art and Smell**: Institute for Art and Olfaction, a nonprofit that explores art related to smell.
11. **Agriculture**: Istituto agronomico per l'oltremare, an Italian institute that focuses on agricultural research in foreign countries.

For more information, you can look up "Yao (disambiguation)" if needed.

adult_technical.text:
The term "IAO" can denote multiple entities across various fields:

1. **Music**: IAO refers to an album titled "IAO" by avant-garde jazz artist John Zorn.
2. **Religion and Gnosticism**: In Gnostic tradition, IAO is an archon associated with Jupiter.
3. **Tourism**: IAO marks Iao Valley, a popular tourist destination in Maui, Hawaii.
4. **Aviation**: IAO is the IATA code for Sayak Airport (also known as Siargao Airport) located in Surigao del Norte, Philippines.
5. **Ancient Semitic Languages**: IAO represents an early Greek form of the tetragrammaton, the divine name of God.

Additionally, "IAO" can stand for several organizations and concepts:

1. **Incorporated Association of Organists** (IAO): A professional association for organists.
2. **Indian Astronomical Observatory** (IAO): Home to the world's highest telescope.
3. **Information Awareness Office** (IAO): A division within the U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA).
4. **Psychographic Variables** (IAO): Refers to interests, activities, and opinions used in market research.
5. **International Accreditation Organization** (IAO): Based in Houston, Texas, this organization provides accreditation services.
6. **International Academy of Osteopathy** (IAO): An international educational institution offering osteopathic training.
7. **International Astronomy Olympiad** (IAO): An astronomy competition for high school students.
8. **Interparliamentary Assembly on Orthodoxy** (IAO): An organization comprising parliamentarians from Eastern Orthodox churches.
9. **Institut d'Asie Orientale** (IAO): A research center at Université Lumière-Lyon 2 and Institut d'études politiques de Lyon, focusing on East Asian studies.
10. **Institute for Art and Olfaction** (IAO): A non-profit organization dedicated to the study of art and olfaction.
11. **Istituto agronomico per l'oltremare** (IAO): A technical and scientific institute under the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs focused on agricultural research in overseas territories.

For further reading, see the disambiguation page for "Yao."

samples.title: 499 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 499 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In the Roman Empire it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus (or, less frequently, year 255 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 499 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Greece 
 After a failed attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in  501 BC (on behalf of the Persians), Aristagoras, tyrant of Miletus, to save himself from the wrath of Persia, plans a revolt with the Milesians and the other Ionians. With the encouragement of Histiaeus (his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus), Aristagoras induces the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the Ionian Revolt and beginning the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene is stoned to death.
 Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which has been under Persian suzerainty since approximately 514 BC, joins the Ionian revolt. He seizes the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians.
 Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, but the Spartans are unwilling to respond.

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 499 BC, which was before the Julian calendar began, the Roman Empire called it the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus. This year, 499 BC, is also known as the 255th year since Rome was founded.

Events:

Greece:
In 501 BC, a leader named Aristagoras tried to take over an island called Naxos on behalf of the Persians but failed. To avoid punishment from the Persians, he decided to start a rebellion. With help from his father-in-law, Histiaeus, who used to be the ruler of Miletus, Aristagoras convinced the cities of Asia Minor to rebel against the Persians. This led to the Ionian Revolt and started a long war between Greece and Persia. The leader of Mytilene, who supported the Persians, was killed by being stoned.

Miltiades the Younger, who ruled a place called the Thracian Chersonese, joined the rebellion. He took control of two islands, Lemnos and Imbros, from the Persians.

Aristagoras asked for help from Cleomenes I, the king of Sparta, to fight against the Persians. However, the Spartans did not want to help.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 499 BC, which was before the Julian calendar was introduced, the Roman Empire marked it as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus. This year, like many others, had significant events that shaped history.

In Greece:
In 501 BC, a leader named Aristagoras, who ruled over a city called Miletus, tried to take back control of an island called Naxos for the Persians. However, his attempt failed, and he faced punishment from the Persians. To avoid this, Aristagoras decided to start a rebellion. With the help of his father-in-law, Histiaeus, who was also a former ruler of Miletus, Aristagoras convinced the Greek cities along the coast of Asia Minor to rebel against the Persians. This led to what is known as the Ionian Revolt and marked the beginning of the Greco-Persian Wars, a long conflict between Greece and Persia. During this time, the local ruler of Mytilene, another Greek city, was killed by being stoned for supporting the Persians.

Aristagoras then reached out to Cleomenes I, the king of Sparta, asking for support in his rebellion against the Persians. However, the Spartans were not interested in helping him.

Another Greek leader, Miltiades the Younger, who controlled a region called the Thracian Chersonese, which had been under Persian control since around 514 BC, joined the Ionian revolt. He managed to capture two islands, Lemnos and Imbros, from the Persians.

This year, 499 BC, is now remembered as a significant turning point in history due to these events.

adult_technical.text:
In the year 499 BC, according to the pre-Julian Roman calendar, significant events transpired that would set the stage for the Greco-Persian Wars. This year corresponds to the 255th year since the founding of Rome (Ab urbe condita).

### Events

#### Greece

**Ionian Revolt**
Following a failed attempt to subdue the island of Naxos on behalf of the Persian Empire in 501 BC, Aristagoras, the tyrant of Miletus, sought to avoid retribution from Persia by inciting a rebellion among the Ionian cities. Encouraged by his father-in-law, Histiaeus, who had previously ruled Miletus, Aristagoras succeeded in convincing the Ionian cities in Asia Minor to rise up against Persian rule, marking the onset of the Ionian Revolt. This act initiated the Greco-Persian Wars, a series of conflicts between the Greek city-states and the Persian Empire. As a result of the revolt, the pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene was executed by stoning.

**Miltiades the Younger's Rebellion**
Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which had been under Persian suzerainty since around 514 BC, joined the Ionian revolt. He seized control of the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persian Empire.

**Spartan Involvement**
Aristagoras attempted to seek support from Cleomenes I, the king of Sparta, for his anti-Persian efforts. However, the Spartans were unresponsive to his request, indicating their reluctance to become directly involved in the conflict at this stage.

These events in 499 BC laid the groundwork for the broader conflict between the Greek city-states and the Persian Empire, setting the stage for the subsequent battles and alliances that would define the Greco-Persian Wars.

samples.title: Mary Township, Norman County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Mary Township is a township in Norman County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 102 at the 2000 census.

Mary Township was organized circa 1880, and named for Mary Thomas, the wife of a pioneer.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.4 square miles (91.8 km2), all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 102 people, 39 households, and 29 families residing in the township. The population density was 2.9 people per square mile (1.1/km2). There were 42 housing units at an average density of 1.2/sq mi (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 94.12% White, 5.88% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 5.88% of the population.

There were 39 households, out of which 38.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 76.9% were married couples living together, and 23.1% were non-families. 23.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.62 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.4% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 33.3% from 25 to 44, 19.6% from 45 to 64, and 14.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 121.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $43,214, and the median income for a family was $44,000. Males had a median income of $38,750 versus $21,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,836. There were 5.3% of families and 9.9% of the population living below the poverty line, including 14.3% of under eighteens and 9.5% of those over 64.

References

Townships in Norman County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: 650s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 659 BC – 650 BC.

Events and trends
Occupation begins at Maya site of Piedras Negras, Guatemala.
First evidence of written Olmec language from the New World.  Pyramid building continues.
657 BC—Cypselus becomes the first tyrant of Corinth.
657 BC—The Li Ji Unrest is a series of events from 657BC to 651BC that takes place during the Spring and Autumn Period, caused by Li Ji, the concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, in order to put his son Xiqi onto the throne of Jin.
656 BC—Psamtik I extends his control over all of Egypt. End of Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
653 BC—Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II succeed Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak as kings of the Elamite Empire.
652 BC—Babylonia rises in revolt under Shamash-shum-ukin against the Assyrians.
652 BC—Guan Zhong urges the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of the other states by refusing the offer of the son of a recently defeated state's ruler to ally himself with Qi if Qi would help him depose his father.
651 BC—Zhou xiang wang becomes King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
650 BC—The town of Abdera in Thrace is founded by colonists from Clazomenae.
 First evidence of writing in the New World, among the Olmec Winters, C.A. (1984a). Blacks in ancient America. Colorlines, 3(2), 27–28.
650 BC—A climate change affects all the Bronze Age cultures in Europe with colder and wetter climate, and tribes from the Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures are pushed downwards into the European continent.
650 BC–625 BC—Wine pitcher (oinochoe), from Rhodes, is made. It is now at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

Significant people
 653 BC—Death of Tantamani, last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt
 652 BC—Death of Zhou hui wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China
 652 BC—First recorded mention of King Kuras of Parsumas, possibly the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, head of the Achaemenid dynasty

References

easy_general.text:
This article covers events and changes from 659 BC to 650 BC.

### Events and Trends

- **Guatemala**: People started living in a place called Piedras Negras.
- **Mexico**: The first signs of an ancient writing system were found among the Olmec people.
- **Corinth, Greece**: A man named Cypselus became the first person to rule Corinth without the support of the people.
- **China**: A ruler named Zhou Xiang Wang became the new king of the Zhou Dynasty.
- **Egypt**: A leader named Psamtik I took control of all of Egypt, ending a previous dynasty.
- **Iran**: Two new kings, Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II, took over the Elamite Empire.
- **Iraq**: The city of Babylon rebelled against the Assyrians.
- **China**: Guan Zhong advised the Duke of Qi not to join forces with a defeated rival's son.
- **Thrace**: A town called Abdera was built by people from another place named Clazomenae.

### Important People Who Died

- **Tantamani**: The last king of Egypt’s Twenty-fifth Dynasty died in 653 BC.
- **Zhou Hui Wang**: The king of the Zhou Dynasty in China passed away in 652 BC.
- **Kuras of Parsumas**: This was the first time someone mentioned a king named Kuras, who might have been the same as Cyrus I, the first king of the Achaemenid dynasty.

### Climate Change

Around 650 BC, the weather changed in Europe, becoming colder and wetter. This affected many ancient cultures, especially those in Scandinavia, who moved south into Europe.

### Artifacts

In 650 BC, a wine pitcher was made on the island of Rhodes. This pitcher is now kept in the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

adult_non_technical.text:
This article covers significant events and developments between 659 BC and 650 BC, a period spanning about a decade in ancient history.

### Major Events and Trends

- **Guatemala**: People started settling at the Maya site of Piedras Negras, marking the beginning of occupation there.
- **Olmec Writing**: Archaeologists found the earliest known written records of the Olmec language, which were inscribed in what we now call the New World.
- **Pyramids**: Construction of pyramids continued, suggesting ongoing religious or cultural activities.
- **Corinth**: In 657 BC, a man named Cypselus became the first person to rule Corinth without the consent of the citizens, essentially becoming a tyrant.
- **Jin State**: From 657 BC to 651 BC, a woman named Li Ji, who was a concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, orchestrated a series of events to place her son, Xiqi, on the throne of Jin.
- **Egypt**: In 656 BC, Psamtik I expanded his control over all of Egypt, ending the rule of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
- **Elamite Empire**: In 653 BC, two new rulers, Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II, took over as kings of the Elamite Empire after their predecessors, Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak, stepped down.
- **Assyria**: In 652 BC, Babylonia rebelled against the Assyrians under the leadership of Shamash-shum-ukin.
- **Qi State**: The same year, Guan Zhong advised the Duke of Qi not to ally with a recently defeated state’s ruler, urging Qi to maintain its independence and respect among other states.
- **China**: In 651 BC, Zhou Xiang Wang ascended to the throne of the Zhou Dynasty in China.
- **Thrace**: Around 650 BC, a group of people from Clazomenae established a new town called Abdera in Thrace.

### Climate and Cultural Shifts

- **Europe**: Around 650 BC, a significant climate change occurred, leading to colder and wetter weather. This affected many Bronze Age cultures in Europe, causing tribes from the Nordic Bronze Age in Scandinavia to move southward into Europe.

samples.title: Visualization
samples.original_text:
Visualization or visualisation may refer to:
Visualization (graphics), the physical or imagining creation of images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message
 Data visualization, the graphic representation of data
 Information visualization, the study of visual representations of abstract data 
 Music visualization, animated imagery based on a piece of music
Mental image, the experience of images without the relevant external stimuli
 "Visualization", a song by Blank Banshee on the 2012 album Blank Banshee 0

See also
 Creative visualization (disambiguation)
 Visualizer (disambiguation)
 
 
 
 Graphics
 List of graphical methods, various forms of visualization
 Guided imagery, a mind-body intervention by a trained practitioner 
 Illustration, a decoration, interpretation or visual explanation of a text, concept or process
 Image, an artifact that depicts visual perception, such as a photograph or other picture
 Infographics

easy_general.text:
Visualization can mean different things:

1. **Creating Images**: This is about making pictures, diagrams, or moving images (animations) to help explain ideas. For example, drawing a map to show how to get somewhere or creating a video to show how something works.

2. **Showing Data**: This involves using charts and graphs to represent numbers and information. For instance, a bar graph showing how many books each person read last year.

3. **Understanding Information**: This is the study of ways to make complex information easier to understand through visuals. Think of it like breaking down a big puzzle into smaller, easier-to-understand pieces.

4. **Music Visualization**: This is when you see moving images while listening to music. It's like watching a movie that changes with the tune of a song.

5. **Mental Pictures**: These are images you see in your mind without actually seeing them with your eyes. For example, when you close your eyes and imagine what your house looks like.

6. **A Song**: There’s a song called "Visualization" by a band named Blank Banshee, which is on their 2012 album.

Some related terms include:

- **Creative Visualization**: This is about using your imagination to create positive thoughts and images to achieve goals.
- **Visualizer**: This term can refer to someone who creates visual content or a tool that helps visualize data.

**Graphics**:
- **Graphical Methods**: Various ways to visually represent information, like pie charts or line graphs.
- **Guided Imagery**: A technique where a trained person helps you use your imagination to relax or solve problems.
- **Illustration**: Adding pictures to explain or decorate a story or concept.
- **Image**: A picture or photo that shows something.
- **Infographics**: Combining text and graphics to make information easier to understand, like a chart showing the growth of a plant over time.

adult_non_technical.text:
Visualization can mean different things depending on the context. Here’s what each term generally refers to:

1. **Visualization (Graphics)**: This involves creating pictures, diagrams, or moving images (animations) to help explain or show something. It's like making a drawing or a video to make a point clearer.

2. **Data Visualization**: This is about turning numbers and information into charts, graphs, and maps. It helps us see patterns and understand complex data more easily.

3. **Information Visualization**: This is the study of how we can represent information visually. It’s all about finding the best ways to show data so that people can understand it better.

4. **Music Visualization**: This is when you see images move or change based on the music playing. It’s like watching a video that reacts to the sounds you hear.

5. **Mental Image**: This is when you imagine a picture in your mind without actually seeing it. For example, when you think about your house, you might have a mental image of it.

6. **Visualization** (as a song): There’s a song called “Visualization” by a band named Blank Banshee, which is on their 2012 album.

In addition to these, there are other related concepts:

- **Creative Visualization**: This is about using your imagination to create positive mental images to achieve goals or change your mindset.
- **Visualizer**: This term can refer to someone who creates visual content or software that generates visuals.

**Graphics** and **Illustration** are both about creating visual content, but illustrations are often used to explain or enhance written material, while graphics can be more general.

**Infographics** are a specific type of graphic that combines text and images to present information in a clear and visually appealing way.

**Guided Imagery** is a technique where a trained person helps you use your imagination to relax or solve problems.

These terms all relate to the art and science of making information easier to understand through visual means.

adult_technical.text:
The term "visualization" can encompass several distinct but related concepts:

1. **Visualization (Graphics)**: This refers to the process of creating physical or mental images, diagrams, or animations to convey information or ideas effectively. It involves the generation and manipulation of visual elements to communicate messages.

2. **Data Visualization**: Specifically, this is the practice of representing data visually through graphs, charts, and other graphical means. The goal is to make complex data more accessible and understandable by leveraging visual cues.

3. **Information Visualization**: This is a field of study focused on the visual representation of abstract data. It aims to enhance human understanding of large, complex datasets by transforming them into visual formats that can be more easily comprehended.

4. **Music Visualization**: This involves the creation of animated imagery that corresponds to musical pieces, often used in live performances or multimedia presentations to enhance the auditory experience.

5. **Mental Image**: This is the subjective experience of perceiving images in the absence of corresponding external stimuli. It is a cognitive phenomenon where individuals can visualize scenes, objects, or events internally.

6. **"Visualization" by Blank Banshee**: This is a song from the 2012 album "Blank Banshee 0," which likely uses the term in a metaphorical or artistic context rather than a technical one.

### Related Concepts

- **Creative Visualization**: A technique used in various contexts, including personal development and creative processes, to imagine desired outcomes or scenarios.
- **Visualizer**: A term that can refer to software tools or devices designed to generate visual representations of data or audio signals.

### Additional Context

- **Graphics**: A broad category that includes various forms of visualization techniques and methods.
- **List of Graphical Methods**: A comprehensive overview of different visualization techniques and tools.
- **Guided Imagery**: A therapeutic technique involving the use of mental images to achieve relaxation and improve health.
- **Illustration**: The use of visual elements to explain or embellish written content.
- **Image**: A visual representation, such as a photograph or drawing, that conveys information or emotion.
- **Infographics**: Graphic visual representations of information, data, or knowledge intended to present information quickly and clearly.

This structured approach provides a clear and detailed understanding of the various meanings and applications of the term "visualization."
